text:
We just shipped a massive latency improvement in a critical Vercel API endpoint. One weird "trick" I've found again and again through my engineering career: move things *out* of the critical path.

The issue is that it's been hard to do this reliably. ğš ğšŠğš’ğšğš„ğš—ğšğš’ğš• is not enough, even though Fluid will try its darndest to run it, it's not a *guarantee*. In most cases, you absolutely need the asynchronous work to happen, no matter what. Network failures, machine failures, code rollouts notwithstanding.

We're fixing this next week btw. You don't want to miss @pranaygp's talk at https://t.co/EcF4k5IhdV â€“ what we'll present is one of the most exciting pieces of OSS.

text:
Excited to welcome Talha Tariq as @vercel's CTO of Security. 

He was CISO & CIO at HashiCorp for seven years, before becoming CTO of Security for all of IBM, including software, AI, and post-quantum cryptography.

We have a shared vision of security through autonomy. Building amazing products, with a great developer experience, no snake oil, no enterprise traps. 

Infrastructure that's secure by default, with agents that help us debug, diagnose, and protect on autopilot.

Privileged to partner with Talha to build and protect the AI Cloud.

Re the last 2 points. We have an amazing startup program and a growing ecosystem of extended servicesÂ²

Incredibly thorough and spot-on comparisonâ° between @aws vs @vercel, from the experience of migrating a production application already in @aws, managed by experts.

While it's obviously nice to win on these comparisons, my absolute favorite part is its conclusion:

> Ultimately, after doing a few tests to derisk we moved our entire application to Vercel over one weekend and deleted a lot of excess code. When we look at our repo now its 99% our application and 1% infrastructure. That makes us happy.

This is the power of Framework-defined Infrastructure (FdI)Â¹. The "mistake" the clouds made is that their entrypoint to building becameâ€¦ their infrastructure.

For @vercel, it's frameworks. SvelteKit, Nitro, Next.js get converted into infrastructure on the fly. 

It's fashionable for vendors to throw the term "lock-in" around, but there's actually an exact way of measuring this. You don't need to take my word for it. Count how many times you "import" or reference runtime APIs that are cloud-vendor-specific in your code (e.g.: Magic Objects, magic "env.*", magic "bindings", etc.) If you stick to framework code, then you can move the workload around, hence the '1%' above being so satisfying.

Last, of course we're proud to build on top of the @aws foundations. EC2, S3, and its global network are second-to-none. Outages are basically inexistent. "POP re-routing" is not a thing. There's no "low-tier network", just the best private fiber network, 24x7x365.

Our commitment to our customers & community is to continue to build Open SDKsÂ², and create the best possible autonomous cloud for them, atop the highest performance 'hardware' we can find.

â° https://t.co/r7ihL96j6t
Â¹ https://t.co/ys2iTSTGTp

text: @schniz You know what you can ship to turn this around ğŸ˜

I re-interview our best performers. 

I set time aside to understand why they ramp faster, ship faster, understand customers better.

Recently I got one of the best compliments about our organization. This engineer came from a really good startup. He joined when they were 20 people and left when they were 50.

But he said that at Vercel, despite being over 10x the size, *he can ship faster than at the smaller startup*. Better infrastructure (dogfooding @vercel) and less bureaucracy, especially around picking up projects and marketing your work.

I think this should be the norm moving forward. Companies can only grow headcount proportional to provable velocity increase. Big companies that move slow are not good for the world.

No need for `cache-control`. In fact you'll notice we send aggressive "don't cache" to clients. Because we want you to have full control of the cache lifecycle on the cloud side.

Cache-control is full of footguns like stampedes / calling origin too frequently on MISS, etc. CF and others paper it over with lots of enterprise proprietary SKUs you have to pile on to make it half-work. Truth nuke.

text:
Vercel Fluid vs Cloudflare Workers.

ğŸ’¬"From my findings, Vercel is 1.2x to 5x faster than CloudFlare for server rendering."

We gave a very, very earnest try to Workers when we explored the edge runtime / world. There's no "beef", we had to migrate off for technical reasons.

To be fair to them, they brought new ideas to the market. The CPU-based pricing for instance was good and Vercel Fluid has it as well.

The main issues we ran into:
1ï¸âƒ£ Bad CPU performance, low capacity, very irregular and spiky latency. The benchmarks show you this.
2ï¸âƒ£ Single-vendor runtime. You can't run "Node.js 24". You run "whatever they give you, which is trying to look like Node.js but it's not"
3ï¸âƒ£ Really bad connectivity to the clouds. We measured the roundtrip time between AWS and CF Workers as being in the low 10s to 100s of milliseconds

The result of us migrating off was shipping Fluid. You pay for CPU, it handles concurrency like a server (cost-efficient), you control the size / memory of the functions, you get full, open runtimes like @nodejs and Python, you get 1ms latency to cloud servicesâ€¦

Most people today are using Fluid and they don't even notice, because it just worksÂ® with the entire ecosystem.

Here are the benchmarks @theo ran: https://t.co/JNFJWmsWZJ

@federicomolina Lexicon helped us name it ğŸ˜‚ we worked with them on the principles & values we wanted to communicate. Naming is design too.

I love Lexicon'sÂ¹ naming framework: your name has to be ğ˜´ğ˜¶ğ˜³ğ˜±ğ˜³ğ˜ªğ˜´ğ˜ªğ˜¯ğ˜¨ğ˜­ğ˜º ğ˜§ğ˜¢ğ˜®ğ˜ªğ˜­ğ˜ªğ˜¢ğ˜³.

Slack is a great name because it's a work app namedâ€¦ slack! Robinhood is a fantastic name for a capitalist stocks app. Discord is a great name aboutâ€¦ community discord!?

An element of playfulness goes a long way in naming things. Tinder being an epic example of that. References to culture (Amazon), science (Google), history (Tesla) are  great too.

Many entrepreneurs think their goal is to pick the concept of word most directly connected or descriptive of their invention and then shell out a lot of money for a .com. There's a better way.

text: @tigerchothani @nextjs Thank you for your support & trust!

A lot of younger people whoâ€™re new to the industry ask me how to do â€œnetworkingâ€. 

How do you go from knowing no one in San Francisco to having a network of people that you can do business with, learn from, hire, etc.

The trick is I never set out to â€œnetworkâ€. Maybe due to Tylenol exposure in womb, or just pure intuition, but I could never fathom that Iâ€™d go to an event or reach out to someone to â€œnetworkâ€. â€œHi this is G and Iâ€™m here to networkâ€.

Instead what I focused on was creating value for others and focus on positive value exchanges. Creating open source projects is the â€œhyper scaleâ€ version of this. Youâ€™re networking with the world, but youâ€™re doing so by leading with value and with content. Writing essays, teaching people things, giving lightning talks, vibe coding an experiment, all more valuable.

What youâ€™re going to notice is that networks build around value, not the other way around.

Even today, whenever I reach out to someone, I try to lead with some insight, datapoint, maybe a bug report or suggestion for their productâ€¦ something tangible. If they have a product or platform with APIs, I start by networking *our systems*.

Iâ€™ve made amazing, close connections to people who I frequently chat with and Iâ€™ve never met IRL. I also make it a point to talk to everybody. Anons, interns, juniors, seniors, CEOs, board members, trolls.

tl;DR: Focus on creating value, think long term, donâ€™t be transactional.

text: @dexkri @JaimeOrtega ğŸ«¶ I actually over the years have gotten many nice notes of people for whom this book directly contributed to landing dream jobs or switching careeers. Which is relevant to the discussion.
@Celmaun @JaimeOrtega Except they didnâ€™t exist, and I wrote the software being taught (mongoose, https://t.co/KQPuGDueUN) and substantially contributed to the others

Some facts. The visa thatâ€™s been fueling Silicon Valley is O-1, not H-1B. Itâ€™s called â€œIndividual of Extraordinary Abilityâ€. It costs about $1000 to applyÂ¹ and itâ€™s unchanged.

But what it also costs is the burden of proof of contribution. Itâ€™s the visa I got as an Argentinian national. And it put me through the wringer.

As evidence to obtain it, I submitted being a Wiley-published book author, press coverage, letters of recommendation from leaders of the field, commanding a high salary, participation in industry associations and events, the impact of my open source contributions, and more.

This country is so great and so worth fighting for, that I put an immense amount of work into my application.

I believe any reward as appealing and compelling as getting to move to the USA is bound to face widespread abuse. The best possible immigration policy will balance keeping the bar really high, ensuring people who love this country, culture, and values, and are willing to work hard get their shot at the American Dream, but never doing so at the expense of those already here.

Â¹ For a small startup, excluding lawyer fees https://t.co/j6ZUDJwoFJ

Thereâ€™s a sales meme â€œdonâ€™t mistake busy-ness with businessâ€ that points to the fact that you might take pride in spending lots of time in meetings, sending emails, making phone calls, but at the end of the day you have to close business.

The same goes for engineering. Itâ€™s not about how much code you write, how much you talk about how much code you write on @x, how many PRs you open. You have to land measurable, impactful results for users.

One of my predictions for the AI engineering age is that the focus on skillset will shift overwhelmingly towards this kind of business acumen. The coding skillset depreciates, what appreciates is knowing what to build. Where to spend your time and tokens. What you get busy with.

text: @adamzwasserman Vibe coding platforms are creating lots of little projects. Each of them having a full blown database is v high in overhead. SQLite fits the mold
@NithurM @orenaksakal @nextjs @Cloudflare Great point. Theyâ€™ll probably migrate after they get tired of Workers vendor lock-in (half baked Node compat and lots of weird runtime semantics)

True. Some of the most educational experiences of my life:

â–ªï¸ Built lots of little web frameworks and ORMs in PHP. Iâ€™d set up constraints like â€œhas to be a single fileâ€ or experimenting with new syntax or language features.

â–ªï¸ Built my own container engine and K8S-style orchestrator. Learning about Linux namespaces, seccomp, networking, squashfs was amazing. I also paradoxically developed massive respect for K8S even though I donâ€™t want to use it. Creating a system that can schedule and run so many â€œkindsâ€ of things, in such disparate environments, is mind-bogglingly difficult.

â–ªï¸ I rolled my own React. My own VDOM diffing algorithm, functional syntax, reactive values, etc. There were aspects of my design that could have been â€œbetterâ€ but I realized React would continue to evolve and win. I learned that a growing ecosystem consensus has as much â€œtechnicalâ€ merit as performance or API shapes.

If youâ€™re an engineer or engineer-in-the-making, thereâ€™s never been a better time to reinvent the wheel. Get busy vibe-re-implementing things and youâ€™ll learn a lot.

text:
Turso is an incredible technical feat. A Rust rewrite of sqlite, with an async-first architecture, incoming support for concurrent writes, vector search, and browser / wasm support out of the box.

I think this has a very good chance of being a foundational piece of infrastructure of the vibe-coding age. On-demand, sqlite-compatible global databases that can also run in-browser and on-device.

The pace at which the project is evolving is most definitely *not normal*. @penberg and @glcst are built different.

Demo: https://t.co/CDjYwGZMNo

text: @10xcalculator Who's the loser? The anonymous account insulting and name-calling, or the builder who reflects on the growth and reach of their creation. Food for thought.

Customer removed a proxy in front of @vercel and saw a 50% reduction in TTFB. What's cool about this view is that it's Speed Insights, which grabs data from end users devices. It's as close as you can get to the truth.

Generally speaking, developers get too caught up on "how it feels on my machine" or "I saw some random benchmark on the internet".

I encourage you to always look at the field data to draw conclusions. Hence why this is called "RUM" (Real User Monitoring). Any RUM tool should work (@getsentry, @datadoghq, etc).

https://t.co/4sBMW0LKZ6

text: @EstebanSuarez @evilrabbit_ @sonofalli @max_leiter @gaspargarcia_ @iansbrash Hay equipo
@0xAvious We do. Top metric starts with quality and speed though. Happy customers > AI

[4/4] Our support team is absolutely cracked, and I'm extremely thankful for their dedication to our customers. So I spent quite a bit of time to debugging how we can make our own support experience better with AI.

Even though we already answer tickets with AI, and even though we already have a 'AI support assistant' for the behind-the-scenes, there's still huge amounts of alpha.

Some takeaways:

â–ªï¸ A lot of the support AI tools were conceived as one-shot assistants. What we've learned with @v0 is that there's a 100x upside in upgrading from "models" to "agents".

â–ªï¸ We're working on content drafting agents that allow us to take common patterns and best practices and create durable content from them. Great opportunity for dogfooding our AI Cloud capabilities.

â–ªï¸ Support Engineers are absolutely crucial and AI is not replacing them anytime soon ğŸ˜Š AI is getting rid of the uninteresting tickets. The ones that remain require significant effort and creativity to tackle, and, crucially, inform product roadmap and decisions. 

I expect AI to continue to have an enormous impact here though. We're not nearly 10% done accelerating delivering quality help to users, and there's a lot more we can do to help them help themselves.

text:
[3/4] A customer was having issues understanding the lifecycle of Image Optimization.

They updated an image on their DAM (place where they host images), but the optimized cache copy was not reflecting a change.

This uncovered a few issues:
â–ªï¸ The TTL behavior is hard to understand. We respect ğ™²ğšŠğšŒğš‘ğš-ğ™²ğš˜ğš—ğšğš›ğš˜ğš•, but there's also a ğš–ğš’ğš—ğš’ğš–ğšğš–ğ™²ğšŠğšŒğš‘ğšğšƒğšƒğ™» param. It's hard to understand this and we could do better docs and observability wise
â–ªï¸ DAMs should be able to trigger a preemptive revalidation of our cache. Customers should not have to wait. We're working on the CDN APIs to tell Vercel "recompute this value in the background, and only replace the cache if it works and is error-free". This is basically what Next.js ISR does and it's a Godsend, but we're going to give you platform APIs for it.

One of the common reminders I get when operating at Vercel scale is that there's no such thing as too much observability. There's endless appetite for more logs, more traces, more ways to inspect the behind the scenes of the machine.

text:
[2/4] A customer from a large consulting group was having issues with the deployment pipeline. It was a high priority ticket due to the SLA we honor and criticality of the project.

It was a very unusual edge case related to exceeding function size from a large dependency. The "build" phase was fine, but the "deploy" phase was not. I recommended two things:

â–ªï¸Little known fact. Vercel CLI has a command called ğšŸğšğš›ğšŒğšğš• ğš‹ğš’ğšœğšğšŒğš that performs a binary search so that you can try out Deployment URLs and find the one that introduced the regression. It's a life-saver

â–ªï¸Try to identify accidental importing of large deps, look at the output of ğšŸğšğš›ğšŒğšğš• ğš‹ğšğš’ğš•ğš, and use the bundle analysis tools in Next.js 

Overall, the big takeaway here is that we have an opportunity to do better in the logs view and help you explore the inputs and outputs better.

We're also working on Vercel Agent automatically helping diagnose issues and open PRs, which should help in the future.

text:
[1/4] A customer wanted a 'vibe check' on how to implement an Age Gate that preserved SEO. i.e.: normal users get presented with the Age Gate, but Google goes through.

When they implemented it naively, their SEO tanked. I went to @v0 and ended up creating a demo on how to implement this with Middleware that I've now contributed to Community.

You can see it here: https://t.co/lsk79ehhe3 (press 'Built in v0' to access the template).

(Note: while 'cloaking' is usually frowned upon, Google makes exceptions for age gating for legal reasons: https://t.co/rT0W6flbx3)

text:
I just completed my routine 'CEO does Support' rotation. If you got a support ticket reply from 'Martin', it was me ğŸ˜

Some cool things I got to help with, pain I got to simmer in, and the answer to the question of whether AI can replace support teams ğŸ§µ

The amount of code being written is growing exponentially. Reviewing is the new bottleneck, not coding.

Vercel Agent captures the ideal workflow you'd hope a peer programmer with infinite energy would perform for every pull request:

â–ªï¸ It clones, installs deps, type checks, lints your code
â–ªï¸ It's an expert in your tech stack
â–ªï¸ It has a great signal : noise ratio 
â–ªï¸ It comments but also applies fixes to the PR
â–ªï¸ It thinks 'adversarially'. Its goal is to vibe check

People who've tried it consistently tell us it's hard to imagine going back to a world without it.

In our tests, it's captured security vulnerabilities, it's prevented outages, and made significant performance improvements. It's spotted edge cases that expert engineers fail to identify.

Give it a try and let me know how it goes ğŸ«¶

The two sides of vibe coding:

1ï¸âƒ£ Vibecoding is a product 
 v0, Lovable, Bolt. Lots of demand for bespoke app, site, agent development with natural language.

2ï¸âƒ£ Vibecoding is a feature 
Data is already systems of record (Salesforce, Snowflake, SAP). Bring the vibes to the data.

I think the opportunity around 2ï¸âƒ£ is under-explored. Further, itâ€™s very likely thereâ€™ll be vertical-specific and constrained flavors of vibe-coding.

This is where can Vercel help. In two flavors. You can use @v0â€™s API to integrate its capabilities and agent into any app. Check out the example below.

If you need something more advanced, you can use our AI Cloud and access the building blocks: AI Gateway, Sandbox, Fluid, etc. We shipped an â€œopen-source, DIY v0â€ in https://t.co/eNaZhAZ9c5.

tl;DR: time to lock in and ship

What first attracted me to Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies was that the Internet lacked a digital money protocol.

HTTP is the universal information protocol. When HTTP/1.1 was introduced in 1999, ğŸ°ğŸ¬ğŸ® ğ—£ğ—®ğ˜†ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—¥ğ—²ğ—¾ğ˜‚ğ—¶ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—± was specified as a standard response. Ahead of its time. Money is information.

Fast forward to 2025 and itâ€™s clear that the term â€œuser agentâ€ was also foretelling. AI agents will perform tasks on our behalf and in doing so will have to exchange information and transact.

x402 is pioneered by @coinbase as an open payment protocol. This is an idea whose time has come. Excited to make it available to our developers using @aisdk and shipping MCP serversâ€¦ in like 3 lines of code.

Thereâ€™re two broad categories of AI workloads weâ€™re seeing on @vercel:

1ï¸âƒ£ AaaS: agent-as-a-service 
2ï¸âƒ£ DIY agents

Most of the successful, sticky Enterprise adoption today is in â‘ : procuring AaaS.

This is why ChatGPT Enterprise is ripping and why @v0 is virally spreading in the Fortune 500. Itâ€™s doing so at a speed weâ€™ve never seen in cloud infra products. @chatbase is another cool example of a high growth startup with an extremely simple adoption model.

DIY agents today are more reliant on the forward-deployed engineer model. Itâ€™s hard for Enterprise companies to go from 0 to 1 on agents on such a fast moving space.

This is what we want to unlock with @aisdk and the @vercel AI Cloud. The cloud won in the first place because companies have very business-specific problems. They need to build custom agents as well as agent platforms. Weâ€™ll make this extremely easy to do. Weâ€™re building the cloud services of this new generation (CDN of AI: AI Gateway, Lambda of AI: Fluid, EC2 of AI: Sandboxâ€¦).

text: @productgremlin Thank you. Goal was not to 'brand' this. It's an open source template, not a product. Maybe we'll change it!
@kradleai Cool
@Mafexuwu @nodejs And that's just one thing. Serverless gave us great defaults like multi-AZ, scale-to-zero, managed runtime and OS for security patches, â€¦ Lots to love & preserve.

Serverless fixed the 'noisy neighbor' problem (you could argue with a 'big hammer'), which is a very attractive property. Setting up servers with the right incantation of auto-scaling to not degrade quality of service is hard. 

We learned a lot from serverless and keeping the good parts around.

No, and that's a feature not a bug. By running on hyperscaler hardware we can offer things like https://t.co/r1TS01FECz which give you <1ms latency and private networking with the world's top databases and services. With Active CPU it's also very cost-efficient.

That said, we're operating at a level of abstraction where we could take Fluid to other clouds and our own hardware in the future.

text:
This is not a serverless horror. This is what happens when youâ€™re on a metered resources plan. Like Argo, or Hetzner once you go over 1/TB in the US.

The solution is not to tell people that limited resources are unlimited. In fact, when you do that, you just created the next botnet. Or FUD.

Our solution is to invest in security by default (Firewall on by default), anomaly alerting, caps, and common sense policies and customer support practices.

text:
This is a very strong argument *for* @vercel that I strongly agree with. When we tried the edge worker thing, we were seeing 10ms hops between edge and aws region. It was devastating.

Vercel Fluid functions run inside the same AZs and regions as most databases and services in the world.

So, Supabase and Vercel are actually usually <1ms away. They're not in the same physical machine, but I think you'll learn very quickly that's not the great idea you think it is. Networks inside AZs are majestically fast.

Notice I said "services". This also means Vercel is in the same datacenters as most of the cloud services in the world, like Stripe. This is how we run some of the largest stores on the planet, that trust us for their rendering and CDN, and use backends like Salesforce Commerce Cloud.

(We have a product called Secure Compute that actually binds VPCs together inside AWS that's really popular for these use cases)

text: From what I can tell, everyone is locking in Sept-Dec 2025. Itâ€™s going to be an amazing year.
@rashmodd @saltyAom At heart

I just deployed a Nitro project in 10s to Production on the Hobby tier.

The target is the "drag and drop to FTP" experience, and I believe we can do better than 5s actually ğŸ˜, with the advent of incremental compilers like Turbopack & Vite.

But it's worth pointing out what the cloud has gotten us in the meantime.

When I was FTPing PHP files, I had no recourse if something went wrong. Rolling back required manually reverting every mutation to every file.

Thus we invented the concept of "deployment images". The most popular imaging format today is Docker. When you deploy to Vercel, we create an immutable snapshot of every deployment, including static assets, CDN configuration, routing logic, and crucially, the core application server functions.

On Vercel, this gets you a couple things. One thing that people love is "Instant Rollback". We can atomically revert a mistake with a single click, including purging the global CDN caches and updating the config.

Another amazing one, pioneered by DHH's arch-nemesis AWS, is multi-AZ redundancy. It's quite amazing to me that even on the free tier of Vercel, you get not just an insanely high level of network redundancy, but also compute redundancy. You can tolerate entire buildings of a datacenter 'catching fire'.

Because the cloud today runs some of the most mission-critical services on the planet, you can go further. We can deploy these "deployment snapshots" across multiple regions, and fail over automatically. That means not just buildings can go offline, an entire city could go offline and your application would work.

As a fun fact, I share the dream of the immediacy of syncing a file (or maybe even a line of code), and seeing it online. It was one of the major inspirations for starting @vercel. 

There're a few things I can't concede though. 

For example, back then PHP would run as an interpreter, which means that after you sync the file, the speed at which it can be executed was quite limiting, giving a bad experience to end users.

They later introduced an "OPcache" which speeds up the interpreter by optimizing certain codepaths into machine code. 

To us, it's kind of unacceptable that an end-user would have to pay the "tax" of triggering the optimization of your code. That's why we build and optimize your code as part of those 10s (as an aside, it's kinda funny that in his meme the bar is "5s" for not doing this :P).

DHH has been vocally against builds with his "nobuild" movement. This is one of the most incomprehensible and inadmissible parts of his rhetoric. As developers, we're supposed to hurt the user experience for our pleasure. But it's a false dichotomy. We can and will have the cake and eat it too. Compilers are awesome, actually, and the foundation of all engineering.

I'm excited about how awesome the JS and TS ecosystem is getting. Nitro is becoming the foundation for open and vendor-agnostic deployment, and it's lean and snappy. The tooling (thanks Rust!) is getting blazing fast. And libraries like React, Vue and Svelte are becoming very mature and easier to use.

text:
Itâ€™s worth reading my answer in depth. I stick to pointing out technical facts.

The bot aspect is that when I try to engage in productive dialog I find half of the replies or more are weird usernames with the strangest tweets. I love talking about this stuff and sharing what Iâ€™ve learned
@charliedotts @dok2001 Ok bot. I just lay out the facts

What I love about this pitiful answer, which everyone is calling you out for, is that you put Cloudflareâ€™s full, true colors on display.

First, you attack the builders of open source technology, while you continue to try and unsuccessfully profit from it. Youâ€™re in a very challenging position. You rely on hiding pricing from the masses, but you just quote tweeted reality for everyone to see.

I invite everyone reading this to go your pricing page and figure out how much your bandwidth, or anything, costs. You proceed to deceive and say Argo is specialized, but itâ€™s absolutely essential. 

Hereâ€™s data from a public internet monitor (https://t.co/mwWktg7fqX). Everyone is welcome to toggle between Free, Pro, Business and Enterprise.

Due to your capacity issues and challenging economics, in the last 24 hours over half the Cloudflare traffic of North America was routed to Europe. Readers, you got that right. E-commerce businesses that are sensitive to latency and setting $$$ ad and conversion money on fire, you got that right.

This is not an isolated thing. You can read in many of the replies that Cloudflare has very poor connectivity in Europe, with one of the most important networks in the highest GDP sector: Deutsche Telekom[1]. Instead of putting in place a transparent and cost-following pricing scheme, you resort to blaming companies that actually building infrastructure. 

(One of your reply bots even told a customer of yours to â€œditch T-mobileâ€ ğŸ˜† good luck telling users that)

You also should know this full well because during a brief, failed POC we did with Cloudflare, one of the first observations we made to your team was that Brazil traffic was being routed to the US East Coast. You read that right. Thatâ€™s the â€œinfrastructure prowessâ€ that us â€œfront end designersâ€ had to point to Cloudflare over Slack.

You also lie about Vercel not offering Argo in one of your replies. Hereâ€™s the truth nuke: Vercel *defaults* to an Argo-like product. Thatâ€™s why our SKUs are called â€œFast data transferâ€ and â€œFast origin transferâ€. Vercel defaults to premium connectivity without throttling, without mis-routing. And for people optimizing and accepting slowness we offer discounted Blob Data Transfer.

Thereâ€™s also a misconception that you â€œbuild infrastructureâ€. 

The reality is that for the critical foundations, you donâ€™t. You actually *blame* real infrastructure builders, like Telekom, and very loudly and publicly you blamed Flexential[2] for your two-day control plane outage. You also devastatingly went down a few weeks ago when it was uncovered that Workers KV was backed by a single-region bucket in Google Cloud Storage[3]. To put your influencers on overtime â€œwrapperâ€ narrative when youâ€™re such an unstable wrapper that blames vendors is really an all-time low, even for you.

Last, but not least, you should revisit how you engage with customers, vendors, and the broader community. Youâ€™re a publicly traded American company that the world should look up to. Youâ€™re following @eastdakotaâ€™s failed playbook of bullying and trolling not just competitors, but also customers and partners, like he recently did with Stripe and Okta in the past. Similar to the playbook of the large influencers you associate with.

You know better Dane. Weâ€™re ready to partner on the mission of an open and secure internet, but you need to lead with (price) transparency and technical rigor.

[1] https://t.co/9np1Qf8Dm1

[2] https://t.co/WGmNAEv6vC

[3] https://t.co/enzFyX2Nch

I have to say that you're already on some list of some sales rep who can't wait to evict you from their platform.

They want to sell you Argo bandwidth, which is marketed as an "origin acceleration feature", but then charges you money for all, cached and uncached, content.

All the while running a marketing campaign against charging for bandwidth. And launching new products that charge for bandwidth (see below).

They love screenshots like yours because you likely don't care about performance / availability, it looks like big numbers, and it helps them plow more sheep into the funnel.

But the rug pull is coming.

text:
Only those routes were blocked, precisely in the interest of preserving your uptime and preventing our IPs being blocked when your forms get reported to us.

The project was never suspended, but records to indicate that you didn't reply to us when we raised this to you. We reached out around these two paths on August 25, August 27, August 28, August 29, and September 3.

To be clear, our intent is to fully maximize access and freedom on the platform. We have well documented communication channels and a support system for you to sort these out, and we will continue to do our best to keep your project online.

PS: will also dig into how to improve the wording in the email to preserve the urgency but be more clear wrt suspension, which did not happen.

text:
We have two of the top 30 (or 20 depending on how you measure). 

We routinely save massive costs for companies that got trapped into CDN tiers that don't charge them for transparent consumption prices.

The average Cloudflare order form we see gives you arbitrary caps of domain names and data transfer. The sales rep comes back and creates a new price for you.

They force you into buying Argo which is how they start charging for bandwidth. Argo also applies to not just the "origin" lookup, but the cached data transfer. Insane deception.

I recorded a helpful video on how you can jump through 4 hoops of pricing page to discover their bandwidth price hidden in a tooltip:

text:
Yes, but let's be clear. Literally every cloud in the world supports Next.js. Especially VPS. It's just `next start`. It's a node.js server. It's been supported since day 0.

Now, for things like Cloudflare, adapters will make it even easier and provide a consistent interface for them.

But it's always gonna be an uphill battle for Cloudflare because they invented a non-Node.js runtime. They patchwork partial compatibility every day (by hiring Node.js contributors) because they realized their limits are unsustainable.

Weâ€™ve engineered Vercel so that live deployments are unaffected by any gap of availability or performance of our core databases.

How? We employ a multi-tiered caching architecture and a global metadata replication system.

But: what if the database or core region that manages deployments, rollbacks, new projects went fully down? What if our core region suffered from a natural disaster?

At the limit, not being able to revert a bad deployment can be just as damaging as dropping live CDN traffic on the workload.

We ran a successful simulation of this disaster scenario and wrote up on it â†“

Plot thickens. You have Cloudflare in front. They did nothing to stop the attack and proxied us millions of malicious requests.

Our logs indicate Vercel would have significantly thwarted the attack if we had had raw access to the traffic. Automatically.

Recommendation: turn off Cloudflare (disable 'Proxy Mode', fine to use them for DNS). Otherwise our Bot Protection can't be effective.

Whenever you wonder how big the gap between "what AI can theoretically do" vs "how much AI is applied today" is, look no further than Gmail's spam filters.

Multiple times a week, I get a fake notice that my X account has been logged-in from somewhere trying to scam me out of my password and 2FA token. Right into my main inbox. Served in a Gmail app notification platter.
Today's email is from ğš¡@ğšœğšğšœğš™ğš’ğšŒğš’ğš˜ğšğšœ-ğšŠğš•ğšğš›ğš-ğš¡.ğšŒğš˜ğš– and the main call-to-action, the Change Password button, goes to ğš‘ğšğšğš™ğšœ://ğš™ğš•ğšŠğšğšğš˜ğš›ğš–-ğšœğšğšŒğšğš›ğš’ğšğš¢-ğš¡.ğšŒğš˜ğš–/ğš›ğšŠğšğšŒğš‘ğš 

The URL then redirects to ğš‘ğšğš•ğš™.ğšœğšğšœğš™ğš’ğšŒğš’ğš˜ğšğšœ-ğšŠğšŒğšŒğš˜ğšğš—ğš-ğš¡.ğšŒğš˜ğš–. Most of the emails I've been getting also exploit some kind of URL redirect service, most recently ğšğš›.ğšœğšğš›ğšŸğšğš¢ğš–ğš˜ğš—ğš”ğšğš¢.ğšŒğš˜ğš– or ğšœğšŒğšŠğš—ğš—ğšğš.ğš™ğšŠğšğš, a QR code generator service.

Now ask yourself: can this possibly be legit? Well, sadly, to unsuspecting internet users it very well might. This is why you see 'big accounts' get hacked all the time and launch crypto scams. 

To a modern reasoning LLMâ€¦ hell no. I gave the raw source to GPT-5 mini on our AI SDK Playground:
It clearly spells out why this is fakeâ€¦ You would think the creators of Gemini would have nailed this. And to their credit, they likely already have, but the productization of their AI innovations is lagging even within the same company.

(Insert copium about LLM cost etc. 1ï¸âƒ£ I pay for Google One. 2ï¸âƒ£ Extra 'thinking effort' can also be spent on emails that relate to security as in banks, crypto, login security for the sake of protecting users!)

Models are like EC2. If your entire product is to re-expose EC2 as-is, you'll likely be in a tough business.

But: if you write software on top of EC2, now you're part of the cloud economy. As an analogy, if we go by the @redpoint's InfraRed Cloud Infrastructure index, $600B+ of public company value has been created on top of cloud primitives by 23 cloud companiesÂ¹

And that's just public companies, only a fragment of the entire cloud value chain.

I believe the AI cloud economy is going to be much larger. The model is a very important base layer, but there's an immense amount of value to be added on top to ship great products. (In fact, if anything, we've seen that the model layer is fluid and uncertain, having changed or upgraded models probably a dozen times at @v0).

People will want to buy AI applications and agents that solve useful, concrete and domain-specific problems. That are secure, reliable, have a high quality bar, mitigate errors and minimize slop. Models alone are not enough.

Yesterday at @vercel we took an important step towards enabling this future with a foundational piece of our AI Cloud platform: the AI Gateway. It's never been easier to access these new foundations. With a few lines of @aisdk code + a single API key, you get zero-markup, virtually unlimited access to 100+ models. 

The best part: we're partnering with the best labs and inference providers in the world to give you day0 access to new models and increasingly affordable and faster tokens.

We're cooking on more services that integrate seamlessly and lower the barrier to entry and raise the security bar of AI, like Sandbox and BotID. Join us in building the AI Cloud ğŸ«¡

Â¹ https://t.co/q3no5VYHz0

ğŸ› bug0 we're spending an entire week on fixing papercuts, making quality of life improvements, improving performance on @v0. The best ai product is the one that works reliablyâ€¦ Let us know what to fix!

We've been building an AI coding agent optimized for Vercel and web technologies. 

It's extremely exciting. At one point we accidentally disabled it on one of our core repos and our devs almost went on strike ğŸ˜‚

We've been, however, unusuallyâ€¦ "slow" in its rollout process. Why? Security.

Over the past few weeks and months, we've now seen agents and MCP servers succumb to several disastrous security vulnerabilities. File a public GitHub issue and their MCP server will leak private repos. File a JIRA ticket and you'll hijack a developer's machine. Etc.

As far as the solution goes, the good ol' principles of security apply: principle of least privilege, not trusting user inputs (injections), and isolation.

Much of the AI ecosystem has perplexingly evolved around local data and local compute. Local MCP servers. Agents with full access to your *entire machine*. Like, Claude Code runs commands in the same computer and filesystem namespace that has your selfies' albums. 1) What. (Incidentally it's why right now the tech is so annoying to use, with disclaimers, warnings and interruptions everywhere.)

One of the primitives we introduced as part of our AI Cloud is the Vercel Sandbox (https://t.co/KfL3upDdzj). We're extremely excited about this. It's basically an "ephemeral personal computer for agents". You, as a developer, can strictly control what gets into it. For instance, what repos the agent gets access to, or what tools. It builds on a decade of lessons on securing Vercel's build machines, which start instantly, scale to millions of instances per day, and get destroyed after each useÂ².

We can't wait to share it with you very soon, as well as more of the lessons we're learning along the wayÂ³

Â² https://t.co/nptrqIIdCz
Â³ https://t.co/mOdwlh14xU

Some early & evolving thoughts on "agentic DX":

1ï¸âƒ£ More 'hyperlocal reasoning' APIs (like Tailwind)
i.e.: APIs that rely less on 'reading in more context' in order to be interpreted.

2ï¸âƒ£ Less pressure on verbosity. 
While humans' fingers get tired when typing, LLMs emitting tokens do not. APIs like `ğšğšŠğš—ğšğšğš›ğš˜ğšğšœğš•ğš¢ğš‚ğšğšğ™¸ğš—ğš—ğšğš›ğ™·ğšƒğ™¼ğ™»` are good, actually. Explicit, convey semantics, etc. This is also true for logging verbosity, stack traces, etc.

3ï¸âƒ£ Double down on the filesystem 
Claude Code-like agents are reinforced on filesystem operations. They like to `ls`, `find`, `cat`, `head`. Filesystem route organization in @nextjs App Router naturally 'sections off' parts of the application that can get their own specific agent instructions. 

4ï¸âƒ£ CLI ergonomics
CLIs generally need to provide better feedback, have non-interactive modes, and centralize output. An example here is @nextjs forwarding browser logs (currently under a flag) so that agents can have a 'single pane of glass' of debugging info:

Overall, there's a lot of overlap between "good DX" and "good agent DX". I think of making things better for agents as an optimization. If the foundations are not solid, no amount of AI will fix them.

SEO for AI, why you should not block AI answer engines, and the future of the web.

We published an article *today* with updated guidance on databases on vercel. Brand new knowledge.

@grok already has it (impressive!), sources it correctly, and links to our authoritative source, our website. This is good for users and good for the web.

For users, this is the ideal experience. I use Grok myself like this every day. I don't want 10 blue links and a bunch of browser tabs. I want the AI to do the research for me.

For companies, this is the future of getting information out about your products. It's going to be the norm and it'll be bigger than social media. Instead of blocking AI with legacy firewalls, I'd focus on:

â–ªï¸ writing content that matches the kinds of questions people are asking about
â–ªï¸ massively speeding up your content velocity. So many nuggets of wisdom get lost in private channels and groups. Get information out more quickly!
â–ªï¸ shipping agent integrations (like MCPs) and tools/infrastructure that plays well with agents (even CLIs are a good example)
â–ªï¸ offering 1P agentic & AI experiences to your end users. There won't be "one chatbot to rule them all". Build your own!

I've been testing out the upcoming @v0 agent release andâ€¦ I've never had so much fun ğŸ˜

Using a @sketchfab 3d model, I was able to guide v0 to do a pretty good rendition of Stripe Press, one of the coolest sites on the internet.

One of the things you'll notice this week is that you can be much more ambitious & 'full stack' with the things you ask v0â€¦ it makes *a lot* fewer mistakes. Just like any AI, it won't perfectly nail everything and you'll have to provide feedback, but at no point did it get stuck in a *programming* sense.

It had to do some pretty hard things to render this book. For instance, the Sketchfab model didn't have "UV mappings", which as I've learned, is the geometry that describes the 'target' of a texture. I generated the textures using AI itself (FLUX by @bfl_ml is quite insane). Then v0 had to do a lot of tricky math to decide which parts of the geometry constitute the "front" of the book and the "back" of the book.

I got to learn a lot from building this even though I actually didn't write a single line of code, which is a testament IMO to the power vibe coding gives you. I  think we'll see a lot more 'custom' experiences on the web in the coming years, from ecommerce to content, using 3D (threejs), generative video & images, and 3d worlds.

Check it out: https://t.co/EV1iolFHuR

text:
Software 1.0 (SaaS) was a rigid, static form of intelligence. 

Some smart, highly motivated group of software-savvy humans get together, try to spot patterns and workflows in a given domain, smash some Red Bulls, stand up a database, wrap some UI around it, bundle it into a binary, and hit publish.

Buyers are happy theyâ€™re finally understood and cared for by a software vendor. â€œThis company Boopitify from Palo Alto finally cracked the problem!â€

As the product and market matures, more customers join the platform, the initial simplicity erodes little by little. The platform slows down by the endless stream of features, bug fixes, dialogs with nested dialogs, integrations, permission systems, Enterpriseâ„¢ï¸ requirements. The platform eventually gets so generic, it gets dumber, and it makes you, the user, feel dumb and disempowered.

AI cuts right to the chase. Youâ€™re no longer buying a rigid proxy for intelligence. Youâ€™re buying ingelligence itself, measured in tokens. This is, incidentally, the same the cloud did for infrastructure. No more rigid, static, fixed-size data center. Everything is consumed on-demand, and itâ€™s on tap.

The key enabler of this has been code generation. Whether itâ€™s vibe coding, GenUI, or agents, the software we used to code, is now generated. The interfaces we used to design: generated. The prototypes we used to spec: generated.

For vendors, it means rethinking your interfaces. Agents or assistants rather than rigid UIs. MCPs rather than rigid integrations.

For AI labs, it means winning the coding war. Agents need to write and execute their own code to solve problems. 

For infra providers, it means rethinking what the â€œhello worldâ€ app is. Itâ€™s increasingly not web services. This is why weâ€™re building the AI Cloud, made up of AI services, for AI apps, orchestrated by AI agents.

text:
The fastest path to irrelevance: blocking progress. Blocking what consumers actually want: low-friction interfaces.

The internet is changing. The answer to AI is: more AI. Not to block and stagnate.

Our metrics show Perplexity and  ChatGPT have had an extremely positive effect on our business. Developers ask for modern deployment and CDN platform recommendations, the AI tells them to check us out. These today are our highest intent signup sources. Far more intentful than Google.

What happens next: Perplexity, v0 and ChatGPT will *grow* your business. They will sign up automatically. They will buy your product. They will digest your information and make it relatable. They will take action. Claude Code is an early glimpse of this future (try asking it to deploy your React app!).

At Vercel weâ€™re excited to take the opposite bet here. Weâ€™ll give you the AI Cloud and CDN infrastructure to help you integrate with these agents and, crucially, to ship your own.

The other 5%, however, is arguably what made React win among many other "similar enough" things that came before it. 

Had the author not detoured into XML markup extensions, and focused on the fact that Æ’(x) would be a user-defined, ECMAScript, `ğš›ğšğš—ğšğšğš›()` function, this paper would be an all-timer.

text:
The last part of the paper discusses the "WAX" XML language. This is I think where the paper goes astray and commits its major mistake.

It explicitly calls out that dynamism *requires* a extension to the markup language. 

This is the mistake that many predecessors of React made. In addition to ğš(ğšœğšğšŠğšğš) â†’ ğšŸğš’ğšğš , one of the early React-isms was that "it was just JavaScript". While originally it looked "odd" to people that React had put "tags" in JS, it turned out to be right.

Reacts's authors decided that they would not have you learn new extensions to html like `ğšŸ:ğš’ğš`.

Putting tags in JS won over putting JS in tagsÂ²

Â² which Curtis suggests in [0085]

text:
In 2015, I wrote a popular essay called "Pure UI" that synthesizes this idea and speaks to the programming-design convergence we're seeing today:
https://t.co/dUXIpLCi96

Reading further, we continue to be back. For 2000, this is a near perfect foreshadowing of the subsequent 10-ish years of DOM updading hell.

â–ªï¸DOM mutations become very hard to reason about ("authoring difficult"), especially as projects / teams grow 
â–ªï¸An event you don't handle that "self-modifies" the DOM without your intervention (i.e.: updating the "local Data Set") is the crux of the matter indeed.

The automatic update aspect foreshadows that you should not be manipulating the output DOM. You should be manipulating state, and let React reconcile automatically (State â†’ Virtual DOM â†’ DOM transformation).

text:
I love thinking about 'surprisingly large datasets'. For one thing, I doubt the Slack devs knew how many custom emojis I alone would upload, let alone our entire org.

And then there must be a Slack org out there with millions of custom emojis. A version at Vercel of this is deployments. We first imagined it'd roughly map to number of commits per day. Then we started seeing platforms make hundreds of thousands of deployments per day, on behalf of other users.

Another version of this is our CDN routing table. How many routes do you think an application can have? Well, think bigger. Some customers have tens of millions of redirects alone.

A fun example is that in 2009, the "Twitpocalypse" almost happened. Twitter didn't expect that there'd eventually be 2,147,483,647 tweet IDs[1], the largest representable value of a 32-bit signed integer.

Today, X likely does that entire number in a weekend.

It's hard to anticipate how big things get or how they'll be used in the wild, so you shouldn't overthink this. However, these migrations can be quite painful. You might think as an engineer "custom emojis will be a JSONB column in this row". Well, no, they'll eventually be a custom table with 500 trillion rows. And then you'll have to do work that'll mostly be invisible to your users, but is essential to continue scaling.

This is why serious infrastructure systems scale with well-defined limits. For example, AWS DynamoDB has a max document / item size of 400kb. Sometimes it's frustrating to hear that things have limits, but then you grow to realize you *want* the limits and respect those systems more. I suspect that as more of documentation gets precisely derived from code, the last 'kind' of human-specified documentation will likely be the systems semantics that don't map neatly to code, like quotas and such.

[1] https://t.co/axoHzkn9cx

text:
After 2 years of iteration at scale, here's everything we learned about engineering Fluid.

The most desirable (yet seemingly hardest to attain) property of a compute system is *efficient and predictable performance at any scale*.

Serverless as pioneered by Lambda had an unusual set of tradeoffs. It has the potential for cold starts in production, which is a no-go.

What's lesser known though is that it solved for the achilles heel of servers: noisy neighbors, congestion, and inadequate load balancing. 

It did so at tremendous expense (1 "computer" per concurrent request), but it was glorious. I sometimes compare this to you and your friend leave work to go to the same exact restaurant, at the same time, but you both order Uber XLs. You'll have an amazing experience, but it's wasteful.

When we built Fluid, we wanted to have the cake and eat it too. I'm particularly happy with our algorithm that uses 'every available seat in the car' (great for AI apps that wait a lot on tokens), but spins up more computers horizontally as needed. This is something exceedingly hard to get right, even for experienced DevOps teams.

Consumption is the only sustainable pricing model for infrastructure, and now intelligence, at scale. 

Kudos to @aws for pioneering the model where, the more you use of an energy-consuming resource, the more you pay, with full transparency and incentive alignment.

What's become evident is that when you use tools like @v0 or @claudeai Code, you're actually incurring in highly fluid infrastructure spend, unlike traditional SaaS products.

The 'digital workers' you're orchestrating in the form of agents are not dissimilar to spinning up a big compute cluster on demand. And the usage patterns vary greatly by person to person, just like cloud consumption varies from app to app.

ğŸµ On Tea Dating, AI and Vibe Coding security
TL;DR: the antidote for mistakes AIs make isâ€¦ more AI.

I've gotten quite a few pings on the Tea dating app security breach, that leaked 72,000 selfies, driver licenses and IDs. 

There's speculation that 'vibe coding' is the culprit, i.e., AI agents writing code for mostly non-technical users with app or business ideas. 

Given @vercel builds @v0, a platform with 7 app generations per second, and our AI cloud hosts many platforms in this category (like @cursor_ai and @durableai), I thought I'd share my thoughts on this.

First, AI coding is here to stay. Microsoft's @satyanadella reported 30% of their code is now written by AI, Google's @sundarpichai reported 25% last year, Meta aims for 50% by 2026. For younger companies like Robinhood, it's now the 'majority' of its code.

Let's now analyze the particular vulnerability at hand. From the leaks on 4chan and other sources, it sounds like the Firebase cloud storage bucket was exposed to the public. Imagine if you took your iCloud Photos and gave them to the whole internet.

Fun fact: we can actually confirm this because the Wayback Machine crawled that bucket, which is essentially like any other URL on the internet:

(source: https://t.co/SPpmuRPmuG)

So, onto vibe coding. It's true that Vibe Coding has increased the frequency of this category of incident, which we can broadly describe as "any client gets access to all the server data". 2 similar leaks came to our attention just last week, including a viral 'waitlist' app where all the emails were leaked to the client:

Lots to unpack here.

First, this category of issue is not exclusive to AI coding. The best analogy to understand what's happening to programming is self-driving cars. Autonomous vehicles operate with the same tools and platforms as humans (steering wheel, highway), much like AI coding uses existing cloud infrastructure and programming languages.

When I saw this Firebase issue, it reminded me of virtually the same thing that happened to expert human coders using Firebase not too long ago (https://t.co/kiGd1Yjbj1). Cursor, ClickUp, Linear, Notion Calendar and many other apps using ToDesktop were not just leaking 'selfies', they were leaking the entire ability to mutate and run code on your computer ğŸ¤¯ (As a citizen of the internet, I at the time loudly expressed my huge gratitude to the responsible disclosure of the researcher and the speedy response from ToDesktop.)

If we go further back in time, we see this category of issue afflicting "human drivers of code", much like both self-driving and normal cars can both crash, throughout history. The way you find this vulnerability is astonishingly easy. In the case of Tea, it took exactly all of three clicks in a web browser (â‘  View â†’ â‘¡ Developer Tools â†’ â‘¢ Network) and some ingenuity.

For ToDesktop, it was basically the same, but with an extra layer of obfuscation (download the app source, de-obfuscate it, find a Firebase db admin password, now you can push any source code update to these apps).

For Capital One, the same again, but with 2 extra layers: find vulnerability in an app, then find an open 'admin server' (the EC2 metadata server), then get full access to an entire network of computers (https://t.co/297PgBzT7m).

So, it's obvious this issue was common even when programming was wielded by engineering experts, even at banks where the security bar is set really high. With AI, it's likely more code will be written in the next few months alone than in the entire history of computers.

Where do we go from here?

1ï¸âƒ£ More AI. When we saw one of the earliest vibe coding snafus happen in our industry, the @v0 team moved quickly to deploy an agent that reviews the generated LLM code and patches it automatically. Our metrics show that we prevent thousands of these issues a week.

If these issues are easy for humans to detect, they're easy for AIs to detect too.

What's more, this technology can be leveraged for automatically reviewing code written by humans and other AIs. This is an example of a vulnerability caught by our @vercel review agent, which we'll be rolling out more broadly:

What's exciting about this is that this system learns and improves from every review and every incident for every customer, much like the entire fleet of self-driving cars learns from crashes.

2ï¸âƒ£ Agent-native infrastructure. Why is it so easy for an agent to do the wrong thing?

If you're a developer, you know that code that deals with authorization and access to secrets does not belong client-side. It belongs server-side. It's been a well-understood programming practice for years.

And because it's been part of the programming canon, LLMs and agents know it too. Some platforms are not giving the agents the right infrastructure to work with. For example, giving agents production database access to save on storage costs, or giving them a limited runtime (running code in the browser) to save on compute costs.

With @v0, we're working very hard for this 'self-driving car' to not just meet the bar of quality of what a human expert would do, but exceed it. I believe AI will create more secure, more performant, more accessible code, but this time in the hands of everyone.

One of the areas of obsession at @vercel is availability. Every. single. request. is critical. 

ISR was designed to go beyond caching, it's a durable storage system that ensures:
1ï¸âƒ£ Global performance
2ï¸âƒ£ Cache-stampede protection[2]

In terms of speed, ISR can apply to the entire page, or even the initial flush of the skeleton (PPR).

The backend protection side of this is more subtle. When you use hand-roll `cache-control` and you purge, you're opening up a 'hole' for a stampede or "dogpile" to crush your site's backend. ISR prevents that, because we know we can 'de-dupe' invalidations.

Our team worked really hard to design both the framework and infrastructure that prevent this, even if you're getting started.

So much so that you can delete your database and Vercel will keep you online until you recover it ğŸ‘‡

[2] https://t.co/uhnBw7yyNK

text:
It's been fun collaborating with @superwhisperapp, a blazing fast AI speech-to-text app, with support for local and cloud models.

By putting @vercel CDN in front of their model API, they're seeing up to 350ms gains in some geos ğŸ¤¯

To be clear, this is 350ms+ faster by *just* putting a proxy in front backed by our global network. They haven't even replicated their db / compute yet! It's free real estate.

When we talk about 'fast data/origin transfer', this is what we mean. We partnered with @awscloud to back vercel with a fully redundant 400 GbE fiber network backbone. No noisy neighbors, top notch security, no last-mile unexpected rerouting, no free-tier throttling, no enterprise-only POPs or TCP optimizations, no Telekom peering issuesâ€¦

Barrels and ammunition â†’ barrels and tokens

The classic @rabois startup wisdom is that at software companies you need two kinds of people: 

â–ªï¸ barrels: rare, high-leverage individuals in a company who can take an idea from start to finish

â–ªï¸ ammunition: talented specialists (engineers, designers) who execute excellently but need direction and ownership to be effective

In the AI age all the leverage belongs to the barrels. The tools are getting so good they can now effectively take any idea to reality for the right barrel. The ammunition is LLM tokens and parallel agents.

I think this is best summary of how the software engineering market changes from now on (ht @cramforce).

Active CPU pricing on Fluid has saved us 77% on our Vercel bill.

This is the most significant infrastructure optimization weâ€™ve shipped to date. It obviously changes how much you pay, but also the entire experience of using our product.

Over the past year, our own workload mix has shifted. Weâ€™ve been deploying more backends, more APIs, more full stack apps. AI calls have extended the duration of responses. 

Itâ€™s not just us. The web is undergoing a pretty dramatic shift. From pixels to tokens. From pages to agents. From HTTP to MCP. From foreground to background.

If youâ€™re building compute infrastructure like we are, running the code is, perhaps counter intuitively, only the tip of the iceberg. Iâ€™m super proud of what weâ€™ve accomplished, with over 1 trillion invocations, multi-AZ reliability, multi-region with 1 LOC, secure VPC connectivity, â€¦

But beyond the actual compute, the product experience is actually determined by the pricing model and the observability of the system. 

Massive kudos to the compute, pricing, financial infrastructure, and observability teams at Vercel for coming together to ship a truly customer-centric experience, with built-in realtime usage understanding.

text:
If you're looking to learn:
â–ªï¸ full stack Next.js
â–ªï¸ how to build a focused product people love

â€¦ look no further than tweakcn[0] by @iamsahaj_xyz. It's an open-source @shadcn theme builder.

Here's why I'd study this codebase:
â–ªï¸ It does one thing and does it really well
â–ªï¸ It's worked for me every time I've needed it
â–ªï¸ Handles auth really well[1]
â–ªï¸ Uses the @aisdk to power generative themes[2]
â–ªï¸ The product is the marketing, the marketing is the product â˜¯ï¸[3]

Thanks Sahaj for sharing this with the world!

[0] https://t.co/zvJSPNevP9

[1] I single out auth specifically because it's always tricky, both in implementation, but also how to insert it into the user experience correctly. The way Sahaj uses it is the best. You can use the product logged out, but if you want to use ai or share, an interstitial shows up. It's very low friction, and I'm willing to log in because the product already proved its value to me.

[2] I asked it to generate a 'mcdonalds style brutalist theme' and I love the outcome ğŸ˜‚. Makes it so easy to make @shadcn your own!

[3] After you generate a theme, the homepage is tailored to you. He's not unnecessarily dividing the product into a "marketing site" and the "application part". It's just one cohesive golden experience.

ğŸ‰ All https://t.co/jKKZsfkpcN tests are passing for @nextjs production builds.

I asked @v0 to visualize this quite literally monumental achievement by the team. 8294 tests passing.

Turns out that doing realtime physical simulation over 8294 bodies is quite performance intensive. v0 implemented the same animation in 3 different physics engines (matter-js, planck.js, rapier) effortlessly. In three shots it did what would take a human hours or days. We settled on Rapier which was the fastest.

There are many other cool details it nailed. I asked for the falling bodies to increase exponentially. It starts out with a few blocks, then more fall, then it's a torrent of blocks ğŸ˜

I'm very happy about our new Turbopack production builds foundation. At Ship we talked about its multi-core aspect, something Rust could give that JS couldn't for a compiler. `next build --turbopack` can actually use the full power of your computer, or your CI system. This has given Vercel single minute compiles on a gigantic codebase.

Check it out here: https://t.co/BNCrOAUu8n

We'll be likely bumping up these numbers, so that each slice of work can get longer. But combining queues + 13 minute tasks can get you really far and help you build reliable products

Astute readers might be noticingâ€¦ since @vercel now has queues, higher execution times, and active cpu pricing, you can essentially compute forever, affordably.

Frameworks can split work under the hood and express an ergonomic DX to you. So, why split work? You don't want a process to spend 5 hours draining LLM tokens,  then suddenly fail 4 hours and 50 seconds in, and have to star over. Checkpoints are good, actually.

@nikitabase Itâ€™s pre-release so I canâ€™t share. Hopefully itâ€™s out soon!

A good reminder for builders is that someone adopting your product happens in two moments. 1ï¸âƒ£ awareness 2ï¸âƒ£ low-friction first use. People use products when they *need* them.

As an example, someone pitched me their pre-release â€œai-native photoshopâ€ the other day. I went to the site and roughly got the idea. It helped that the product itself was the website so I understood the idea faster by messing with it, rather than marketing fluff.

However, just now I actually had a use case. I was astonished by how good this thing is. It worked first try and Iâ€™m now entering the â€œholy shitâ€ phase. 

The first time I used it was the awareness development moment. If the product builder expected a successful â€œsessionâ€ then, he would have set himself up for disappointment.

The second moment was the crucial one. Usersâ€™ attention spans, propensity to go through yet another tool, signup, etc are very low. That second moment needed to be flawless and it was.

Incidentally this is why you need to really pick your battles with product surface and optimize for quality. Had that second moment not been successful, I donâ€™t know if I would have tried it again for a while. Anecdotally, people seem to do an â€œexponential back offâ€ with products theyâ€™re disappointed by. They wonâ€™t try you again next week, theyâ€™ll try you again in a few months, maybe after another awareness moment in between.

@VijarKohli Each phase of the web has birthed many winners. There wonâ€™t be a single on in the generative stage. The companies that adapt will thrive

Over the past few months Iâ€™ve watched a small, insanely talented team at Vercel live-migrate 100 million functions from a former vendor to Vercel.

Quite a feat of engineering. The scale involved was non-trivial (single-digit % of total vercel functions) but this particular workload ended up being more niche than we anticipated. More on that later.

The more painful lessons are in the runtime engineering aspect. Itâ€™s abundantly clear at this point that nothing can add more tech debt, pain, and degrade the DX more than an exotic runtime with a limited ecosystem. This is why youâ€™ve seen Node.js endure as the standard.

Weâ€™ve designed Fluid to be runtime agnostic from the outset. Our functions run stock Node.js & Python, and weâ€™ll make it easy to bring arbitrary ones while retaining the infra benefits like cold start prevention (â€œscale to 1â€ for prod), multi-region, streaming, etc.

But thereâ€™s an important missing piece. Tune in on June 25: https://t.co/qgIxLgOAFB

@RaffaySajjad Some things you can ship fast, some things you have to ship slow. When leaders understand the engineering deeply they wonâ€™t give deadlines to their teams that are self-destructive

Dynamic config change that uncovers a pathologically slow, expensive, or faulty code path is the most common category of global outages. 

Fastly (June 8 2021)Â¹
We experienced a global outage due to an undiscovered software bug that surfaced on June 8 when it was triggered by a valid customer configuration change. We detected the disruption within one minute, then identified and isolated the cause, and disabled the configuration

Cloudflare (July 12 2019)Â²
On July 2, we deployed a new rule in our WAF Managed Rules that caused CPUs to become exhausted on every CPU core that handles HTTP/HTTPS traffic on the Cloudflare network worldwide

Facebook (October 4 2021)Â³
Our engineering teams have learned that configuration changes on the backbone routers that coordinate network traffic between our data centers caused issues that interrupted this communication.

Thereâ€™s several reasons for this:
- Config changes can happen â€œout of bandâ€, in dynamic runtime systems that are divorced from source control and standard review patterns
- Config changes are sometimes run imperatively by operators. Running scripts, migrations, commands are examples of this
- Even at 100% test code coverage, specific input shapes and sizes can bite you and slip by 
- Config changes can uncover latent software bugs. Like a pathogen thatâ€™s been dormant and gets activated later. It can be very difficult to forensically map the config change to code that might have been introduced weeks, months, years ago. The typical incident response is to look at *recent* code changes 
- The worst kind, as in the Fastly case: multi-tenant systems accept dynamic user configuration changes. In the case of Vercel, we let our millions of users dynamically change any aspect of our CDN: routes, settings, headers, middleware code.

What do we do to prevent this? 

First, know that this is very hard work. Infrastructure work requires extreme attention and paranoia. I sympathize with these teams.

1ï¸âƒ£The first is to treat every change as code. Iâ€™ve shared this banger by @hugelgupf before:

> Configurations, rules, policies, whatever you call them -- they're all code. Roll em out like code.

2ï¸âƒ£ Have operational limits on everything. â€œUnlimitedâ€ is the worst kind of engineering marketing, avoid it like the plague. A system without limits is a system that will eventually go down or not scale properly.

For instance, Vercel applies strict limits to the configuration options we give customers, and we even set upper bounds on the max number of cpu cycles regular expressions can incur in.

Recursion is your enemy. Regular expressions can be exploited via backtracking. Redirects can be exploited by redirecting the host to itself. Etc

3ï¸âƒ£ Broad system changes require careful follow-on monitoring

The worst character trait for an engineering operating at scale is over-confidence. Itâ€™s imperative to monitor the effects of the change. It doesnâ€™t matter what programming language, type checker, effect system youâ€™re using.

Â¹ https://t.co/Jgg6d0UEdf
Â² https://t.co/ZDl72rfkHy
Â³ https://t.co/KxavsO4IxU

If we go by how many people ask me for help recruiting @nextjs engineers, AI has had exactly the impact I thought it would have. Innovation is accelerating and there's an endless amount of work to be done. 

AI has not magically shrunk the "TODO" list of things to ship, it likely has only extended it due to an influx of new ideas and possibilities. I can only speak to our corner of the world, but I've never gotten as many requests for talent as I'm getting now.

text:
I built a @v0 that shows how AI could improve error messages in @nextjs, via @xai grok.

First, I pasted a screenshot of the existing error dialog. The first shot was shockingly good. I used an upcoming ğŸ¤« feature to increase its quality.

I then asked it to add an "AI button" powered by @grok. It came up with the icon, the design, and the whole @aisdk implementation.

The inspiration here:
- Next.js was showing a bizarre error that I could not trace to my application. The source ended up being the SimilarWeb Chrome Extension ğŸ˜¨
- While I figured it out, we get a lot of non-expert users using the framework who get really thrown off by this stuff.
- I wanted to validate whether AI would nail this one (turns out it does!) and what it would look like in the product

@Anay_208 @dok2001 @joseppudev Because itâ€™s a reverse lottery, where if you happen to grow within the free tier, youâ€™ll have to be converted to enterprise where they charge for bandwidth, not only not-unlimited, but with explicit limits that trigger rate renegotiations, to pay for the â€œfreeâ€ of everyone else

What the Reddit post says is consistent with every Cloudflare contract we've seen.

First, very importantly, you charge for bandwidth. Second, you have 'max allocations' on a per item basis. Third, you have a clause in the contract that says that the prices listed do not apply to overages. The enterprise rep can re-negotiate them arbitrarily at will.

This is completely consistent with the extortion the customer is reporting on Reddit. The world needs to know this is how your business model works, and you should be open about it. I honestly don't know how you sleep at night, quote tweeting "it's free!" and then turning around and doing this :/

text:
Increasing convinced observability and monitoring as it exists today will soon cease to exist. Two counter trends: autonomous infrastructure & AI.

Humans staring at plots and charts to derive very obvious patterns like why your API is 500ing is NGMI.

On one hand we have infra that scales automatically and self-heals. A lot of our customers simply donâ€™t set up expensive o11y appliances. Prices will go down to approach the cost of data storage. On the other hand, we have the fact that people donâ€™t want o11y, they want solutions.

They want pull requests with fixes, they want automatic rollbacks, they want automatic fail over of vendors (see: AI Gateway).

Because Fluid is adjusting at the time of integration and tuned for each runtime, itâ€™s more efficient, faster and automatic.

Autoscaling requires a lot of manual tuning, CPU thresholds, and can react too slowly. We all hate cold starts, but a request queued behind an unresponsive & overloaded server / VPS is effectively a cold start or worse.

text: @haltakov Will check with the team. Our default stance is to benchmark against our past selves and recommend customers do their own. Benchmark marketing can quickly end up contrived.

Another example of how AI disrupts everything, from UIs to infrastructure: serverless. You canâ€™t take tomorrow for grantedâ€¦

The model that Lambda pioneered was 1 invocation 1 function instance. This works wonderfully if your databases and caches respond instantly, as they should! This was the norm for SaaS and e-commerce.

When GPT APIs came out and developers saw the opportunity to create AI products, two new profiles emerged:

â–ªï¸ Streaming responses
â–ªï¸ Lots of idle time & long responses

Luckily for us, we had been working hard on streaming in preparation for React Server Components. We knew that for complex frontends with lots of data and components, the best model was to render and return as soon as possible. That investment in streaming paid off.

Idle time posed a significant challenge. A system optimized for fast computation suddenly had workloads that were taking 30s to respond. And then reasoning models come out, and weâ€™re now talking minutes. And then agents come out, and weâ€™re talking hours? Days!?

Our team moved extraordinarily quickly while operating at very large scale. We created ğŸŒŠ Fluid which solves the idle time problem by sending more requests to existing function instances. 

Like a VPS would. But unlike a VPS, if the instance is overloaded and blocked by compute, it intelligently launches a new instance in parallel to accommodate. Think of this as just-in-time, invocation-driven, dynamic load balancing.

The customer win concretely is that weâ€™ve saved people a lot of money. Up to 90% cost reductions for some workloads by just turning Fluid on, which, unlike other solutions, requires no code changes and runs full, off-the-shelf, versioned Node.js and Python.

Weâ€™re very privileged to host many of the most popular AI apps in the world. With one of them we got to see Jevons Paradox up close while in beta. We saved them a lot of money, we scaled with them as the service took off, they continued to innovate and launch new things on Vercel. The savings over time just translated into more service demand, because we helped them win.

Weâ€™ve got a few more things coming to Fluid that I think youâ€™ll love, especially for building these kinds of AI apps. You can read more about this topic here: 

https://t.co/wzzQfSwaBY

Amazon famously popularized the finding that for each 100ms of slowdown in their storefront, theyâ€™d see a 1% drop in conversion.

Weâ€™ve found this effect to be far more pronounced with @v0. Speed and reliability have an outsized effect on engagement and conversion.

Thereâ€™re a couple reasons for this. On a high level, AIs are evolving to be our virtual coworkers. Intuitively, weâ€™d all much rather work with coworkers that respond to our @ pings and emails instantly. Coworkers that get back to us reliably and donâ€™t drop the ball.

These problems are very real in AI today, which is why Iâ€™m so excited about our AI Gateway[1] and investments into reliable streaming[2].

AI can be, conservatively, 10x faster and more reliable than it is today, and this will be a vital part of the race for consumers building the muscle memory in favor of a certain agent, much like it played out for so many of us defaulting to typing amazon dot com.

The vast majority of the world runs on legacy software. Companies know how much greener the other grass is, but itâ€™s so difficult to justify the migration time and pain. I think weâ€™ll look back on the automated translation between languages / frameworks as one of the valuable contributions of LLMs to the industry.

text:
When I started Vercel my singular obsession was â€œtime to deploy URLâ€, in the fewest number of commands and config (`now`).

Our next frontier: time to intelligence. By building on the @aisdk, all you have to do is install the dep:

â–² ~ / npm i ai@alpha @vercel/ai-sdk-gateway

Then run `vc pull` for local development support. Thatâ€™s it.

To try or switch models just swap a string, like â€œğšğšğšğš™ğšœğšğšğš”/ğšğšğšğš™ğšœğšğšğš”-ğš›ğŸ·â€ â†’ â€œğš¡ğšŠğš’/ğšğš›ğš˜ğš”-ğŸ¹-ğš‹ğšğšğšŠâ€. No API tokens. No new accounts. Unified usage billing with observability.

Our AI gateway comes from the lessons of building @v0 and powering many of the largest AI apps today on Vercelâ€™s infra.

The realities today:

â–«AI labs move at breakneck speed. Your best play is to minimize switching costs and preserve option value without lock-in.
â–«The demand for AI is so extreme that even the largest clouds struggle with capacity issues that result in frequent rate-limiting errors.
â–«The infrastructure is not as mature, stable, and predictable as the â€œsoftware 1.0â€ cloud services yet. Backups and failovers are even more essential.
â–«As open models progress, the competition for best price/performance intensifies, because many vendors can serve the weights. You will be able to name the open model ID and delegate the optimal vendor choice to the gateway.

Weâ€™re super excited about the AI Gateway solving these challenges and many more as it evolves. Please try it out and share your feedback!

â—‹ Inbox0, a voice assistant to sift through your email, reply and archive on the go. Demoâ€™d super well.

â—‹ An MCP server that enabled querying anything you see on a given day via AR glasses (â€œwhat did I have for lunch?â€). A working version of Black Mirrorâ€™s â€œThe entire history of youâ€ but with glasses instead of contact lenses.

And many more. Some people from Vercel built a cool React DX for MCP, there was a neat OpenAPI â†’ MCP converter to bootstrap faster, a code migration toolâ€¦ Inspiring to see people ship so fast!

@a_i_m_rue Active area of research for us, we have a few good hypotheses

The rise and fall (and rise) of the CDN.

App developers and vibe coders will never have to think about CDN and WAF as distinct appliances to purchase and configure. The CDN has been turned inside out: its configuration and caching are outputs of the deployment process and Git-driven. This is a major disruption.

Enterprises are arriving to the same conclusion. As they modernize their apps, rewrite them in modern frameworks, and deploy to the cloud, theyâ€™ll realize their multi-year CDN contracts are technically redundant and predatory from a cost perspective, with non-transparent pricing and outdated configuration management (usually ClickOps, developer-hostile and professional services heavy).

But how do we get to the promised land of full automation with optimal global distribution and efficiency? For Vercel this means to continue to invest in framework-defined infrastructure for net-new apps, but also smoothing the road to use Vercel as a pure CDN/WAF to facilitate incremental migrations. Their journey to a high performance, AI-native app will start one microfrontend at a time, with the rest of traffic proxied to the existing workloads.

Over the past few weeks weâ€™ve shipped very exciting CDN and security features:

â–ªVary HTTP header support
â–ª1-click AI crawlers blocking 
â–ªCDN-Cache-Control proxy support
â–ªIncreased origin timeout to 120s
â–ªBetter bot observability 
â–ªEasier custom WAF rule creation 
â–ª1-click Bot filter / challenging 

With lots more to come. Excited to be making all new apps fast and secure, while giving a clear path forward to the large and complex websites and apps we depend on every day.
