@jonkkillian @neondatabase @databricks @v0 Yes. In practice itâ€™s more complex though, the architecture involves transient storage in safekeepers and a multi-tiered cache 
https://t.co/vC7Vb1Ypn1

Congrats to the @neondatabase team on their acquisition by @databricks. Itâ€™s clear that serverless and open source data was not just what developers wanted, but also the ideal foundation for coding agents to build on.

Agents like @v0 favor infrastructure thatâ€™s well represented in the training (Postgres: check). Not re-inventing the wheel and bringing new query languages to market was rewarded.

On the other hand, agents and modern dev platforms like @vercel need agility. Databases need to be created instantly when you prompt or create from a template. During the vibe coding or preview process, the database is needed, but then not accessed for a while.

At rest, a Neon database is inexpensive S3 objects. Modernizing the storage layer, while retaining the â€œfrontendâ€ APIs that agents and devs are familiar with is a winning combination. 

Itâ€™s great to see new players in the Postgres space like https://t.co/QR9Mw4BKzv, https://t.co/BDjniVkUQH, https://t.co/zjjtxnz4aU innovating in the storage infrastructure as well. @Supabase recently announced the acquisition of https://t.co/xNJospTeCl to pursue decoupled storage and compute, while @Prisma is bringing a Unikernel-based approach for instant db boots with https://t.co/6KPUinWmtQ.

Itâ€™s clear now that Postgres has become the Linux of the database world, and the de-facto choice of developers, enterprises, and importantly, agents.

@ajrgd @vercel We have mitigations for our largest customers, including dedicated and BYOIP solutions. The disappointing part is that this affects everyone else.

ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¸ğŸš« Update on LaLiga's blocks. We've been working with their team to ensure uninterrupted access in Spain to the @vercel global CDN.

Vercel has set up a dedicated inbox for LaLiga to file reports. Sadly, they just blocked another Vercel CDN IP without using this mechanism.

To summarize the situation so far:
â—† A soccer organization should *not* have the ability to broadly block internet infrastructure access to millions of Spanish customers across major internet service providers.
â—† CDN providers like Vercel front millions of mission-critical websites and applications behind the IPs being blocked. Even in the situation a block is required, it can be done on a hostname basis via TLS SNI, rather than IP.
â—† We set up an inbox that's tied into our Site Reliability Engineering's incident management system to process high priority requests. It has so far been unused.

We're closely monitoring the situation and continue to offer our assistance to LaLiga to minimize the blast radius of these blocks and help preserve free access to the internet in Spain.

text: The @vercel Chat SDK now features stream resumption. This makes AI conversations resilient to network hiccups and reloading or sharing a chat mid-generation. This is especially valuable for long responses (e.g.: Deep Research). No proprietary APIs, no sticky load balancing, just Redis pubsub.

Improving web performance remains the closest thing that exists to a money printer.

Amazing writeup from the @onequince engineering team on their @nextjs migration, which unlocked an incremental $59M annually and massive agility.

I've now seen so many of these migrations. The coolest part, which they note in the article, is that Next.js is not just a 'faster horse', but provides the platform that enables future experimentation and personalization. Legacy static solutions, or even modern ones heavily reliant on full-page CDN caching, struggle with dynamic and AI-driven content.

As someone in the weeds of the framework and the tech, I get really excited about these stories, because I know just how much *more* performance improvement is still up for grabs.

text: @durantelolo No, weâ€™re actually discussing prioritizing this. cc @RhysSullivan @dillon_mulroy

@AshConnell @mjackson Simplicity of the interface != simplicity of the implementation. This is what it takes to give users the PHP-like model. I didnâ€™t even scratch the surface of other complexities you have to handle like routing, cold start mitigations like pre-warming and bytecode generation, etc.
@WebDev_Anderson @vercel_support @vercel Team is working on a fix

I love this model and itâ€™s what we built with Fluid. 

First, on the shoulders of Lambda, we shipped the 1:1 process-to-request model. The DX was sublime but if youâ€™re waiting on I/O for long it can become inefficient, especially with LLM streaming which can take a while.

Then, since developers were still writing async/await code rather than blocking the main thread and thereâ€™s an ecosystem around it, it was a no-brainer to â€œpackâ€ the already-running functions more densely. Thereâ€™s a lot of intelligence in the system though.

If your function is waiting on a backend, then we can send more requests to an instance. But if your function is doing number-crunching, image transformation, you-name-it CPU-blocking operations, we spin up more. This solves a very tricky, usually-manual and error-prone, load balancing problem.

Weâ€™ll be sharing more technical notes on how the dynamic load balancing logic works, but in the mean time, hereâ€™s a write up. Excited for others to explore this space.

https://t.co/mSX9C6fYKU

text:
Will we hire engineers in the future?

Prompting is thinking. The sharper your thoughts, the better the prompts, the better the outputs. Engineering and design are headed into a world where most of the output is produced by prompting, if not all.

The way we interview engineers has already been trending in this direction. At Vercel, we donâ€™t care if you memorized every API and module. When we look at your coding, we assess the quality of your thinking and collaboration. Itâ€™s more so an evaluation of your â€œthinking tokensâ€ or reasoning trace. In fact, the more you expose it, walking through how you backtrack, pivot, adjust, consult, the better signal we get.

My prediction is that the demand for great thinkers will remain unabated. Itâ€™s unclear if weâ€™ll call them engineers or if itâ€™ll matter, because these people will have a lot of full stack impact on the whole business, as theyâ€™ll have access to prompt their way to any successful outcome.

Yes, these systems can get into chicken and egg problems.

text:
Google Chrome ending up in the wrong hands due to DOJ intervention could be catastrophic for the open web and backfire entirely. 

Few organizations in the world meet the bar of having 1ï¸âƒ£ the webâ€™s best interests in mind, 2ï¸âƒ£ the technical infrastructure and know-how, and 3ï¸âƒ£ the immense required funding.

Working on a browser involves two main areas: the engine and its frontend, like a carâ€™s engine and its chassis & dashboard. Google has done a *phenomenal* job on the engine, which is one of the absolute hardest technical undertakings in the world, and curiously enough is actually fully open source.

Blink, Chromeâ€™s engine, is BSD and LGPL licensed, developed in the open, and powers so many of Googleâ€™s competitors, including Microsoft Edge, Brave, Opera, Vivaldi, Browser Companyâ€™s Arc/Dia, and dozens of others at no cost. Itâ€™s absolutely essential that this work stays uninterrupted, while we continue to invest as a community in engine diversity, including projects like @ladybirdbrowser of which Iâ€™m a proud backer.

And Blink is just one piece, in charge of rendering. Google has built and open sourced many other crucial engine components like the V8 JavaScript engine, Skia, PDFium, Cronet, and many others, bundled as part of the open Chromium distribution. The complexity of what makes a modern browser work is truly staggering. Thank you Google.

The DOJ is taking particular issue with the engineâ€™s frontend, the actual thing consumers download and interact with. This is where Google has the unique privilege to package and distribute the open source engine components, and impose arbitrary rules and configurations on top, like search engine defaults, AI assistance models, telemetry capture, login / accounts integration, settings and history sync, Web Store rules (like which ad blockers can be distributed), etc. At the scale Google is operating and the power it confers, scrutiny and caution here is warranted.

I believe, however, that the best path forward will be an incremental one, maintaining the careful balance of a browser frontend that has the everyday internet citizenâ€™s best interests in mind, while not disrupting the investment and support of such crucial open internet infrastructure that benefits us all.

I think youâ€™re misunderstanding. The Loading transition is prefetched. Thereâ€™s no blocking server in the transition. The server is called to hydrate the data / markup unidirectionally, which is superior to client-driven waterfalls. And that latter part should be optional. Hence where zero could take over

The click is showing a RSC stream, with an instant 'Loading' state, which is what people expect of a SPA. The 'lack of `fetch`' refers to the lack of `useEffect` based, waterfall-y, data fetching.

Our standing goal is to get rid of as many pixels as possible, to leave you with the most essential and delightful ones
Just the beginning

Because we build @v0 full stack on Vercel, we've been able to experience what a successful startup born on our platform would live through, as fate would have it, on an expedited timeline. It's been validating.

Takeaways. The most important thing to optimize for is iteration velocity. We noticed that LLMs were not just good at writing haikus and homework, but also writing React and Tailwind. @jaredpalmer came up with the 'text to React component' interface and launched it extremely quickly.

Since then, *major* advancements have happened in the ecosystem. Model innovations. Better cognitive architectures. Prompting techniques. Retrieval solutions. Tool calls. Integrations. We co-evolved the @aisdk as a universal interface to AI models because we realized the future of intelligence would not belong to one specific vendor.

Today, that single Postgres instance we started with has its days numbered. We'll have to shard and replicate to keep up with demand. But looking back, I wouldn't change a thing. The success of a product is rooted in how fast it evolves. We made the right bets to be able to iterate on the customer experience, while replacing some of the backend components as we went along.

That was the premise with which we started @nextjs and @vercel, as well as open sourcing the tools and best practices of what we learn as a teamâ€¦ so, stay tuned for more of the behind the scenes of our evolving database architecture ğŸ™‚

When FoundationDB was introduced to the world, its cofounders would do live demonstrations of its fault tolerance properties by physically unplugging servers and simulating power failures in one or more machines.

The entire system was first conceived and developed in a fully simulated environment. Actual storage, clocks, and network code came later, once the baseline of confidence was established. Because hardware and cloud engineering has gotten so good, running into these failures is rare, which can lead to sloppy engineering.

This is the ideal acid test that we must run software through. We must first develop in environments in which the proverbial "tripping over the cables" is handled by design. When we ship, we must do so with the confidence that the corner cases are handled.

The corollary is that when you QA your software, you must be ready to unplug the server and see how it responds. Too often I see product people treat their creations like a delicate flower, ignore flakes, blame 'the internet', press the refresh buttonâ€¦ living in blissful ignorance of the pain users will face in the real world.

We're cooking up a mechanism to seamlessly resume streams and share state across Fluid functions.

AI apps pose an interesting challenge to developers: they need to stream feedback in realtime, they have multiple agents behind the scenes, the conversation needs to be shareable, resumable, survive network disconnections.

Even with https://t.co/v6M4VQNaw0, this kind of stuff was non-trivial. You always need a durability source (in this demo below, you can see the 'stream id' in the URL), so a stateful bidirectional transport like WebSocket is *not enough*. Not only is it not enough, it's also not necessary (the demo below uses good ol' HTTP streaming).

Also: what happens if the stateful Node WebSocket server was re-deployed mid-stream? or if it crashed? how do the streams recover?

I'm excited for @vercel to give you all the primitives to execute on applications that raise the bar on not just performance, but also on fault tolerance. h/t @cramforce for sweating the details here.

The cool tech thing here: if you go to `/state-of-ai` right now, you get an instant CDN load of the 404 page. When it ships, you'll get an instant CDN load of the (PPR) survey page.

What makes this a particularly neat feat is that the flag evaluation is instant and globally distributed. In principle, this flag thing would "just" be an extra line in your page render function:

  ğš’ğš (ğšğš•ğšŠğšğ™´ğš—ğšŠğš‹ğš•ğšğš) {

â€¦ but that would force everything into a regional server-render. It'd make everything slower and more expensive. If you're not extremely careful, when you get a spike of traffic it would then denial-of-service your CMS and databases. And this was "just" a landing page!

Vercel solves this with global middleware and first-class support for flags (https://t.co/c8eX4NLbUh) that is easy to integrate on top of your pages, which get statically optimized as necessary (e.g.: with @nextjs). The Toolbar then allows your team to override and simulate the values of these flags.

This is an example of something that has been historically quite hard to do on the web, even though it 'looks' so simple on the surface. You can make it globally fast, reliable, cost-efficient, *and* roll it out in a collaborative way with your team that minimizes risk.

The best technologies humans have invented have tremendous range. They scale up and down in complexity and sophistication.

iPhone: my 1 year old uses it, I do most of my work on it, my 90 year old grandma used it every day.

X: Iâ€™ve been on this platform since it was just niche communities like web dev. Presidents and kings are on the same platform as you and I and @greg16676935420. 

Web: DoorDash got started with an index.html file that attached 8 PDFs of places that delivered food in Palo Alto. The same platform can also support Gmail, X, ChatGPT, @v0, and the most dynamic and generative AI apps weâ€™ll ship in the next decade.

Technology is for everyone, by everyone. Anything that was considered too difficult or out of reach, or only accessible to a small group of experts, like coding or photo editing, will eventually be accessible to all. Thatâ€™s the true unlock of AIâ€¦ the last technology frontier.

text: @jaredrhizor @emoryzanef @vercel Team is on it and marketing email sending has been paused. Thanks for the pings ğŸ™

Helping a customer migrate from an existing CDN to Vercel. This service advertises itself as not charging for bandwidth. 

Extensive marketing plastered all over social media. Imagine my surprise when I look at their renewal order formâ€¦ first 2 items? Bandwidth and Requests.

The reality: the service is "free an unlimited" until their Enterprise sales team gets their hands on you. And they will. They're hoping that you're in too deep at that point. They're hoping that they can crowd social media with enough loud voices about how awesome the "free" service is.

Leaving the business model aside, is this how you want to live? The fundamental feedback loop of engineering is one in which you understand your costs, transparently, and how they scale. You make engineering choices, down to the code you write, based on that feedback loop.

What's astonishing about this order form is just how similar the pricing is to a hyperscaler cloud. Except every real cloud provider operating at scale can't afford to deceive the world, and then play a game of chicken with ToS threats and sales teams. Which is why my prediction is that the music will be stopping soon.

text:
Lots to love about this release.

1ï¸âƒ£ The beginning of arguably the most exciting journey in @nextjs history: Turbopack production builds.

Like with our `next dev` efforts, focusing on the cold case first, we've been able to bring down one of the world's largest Next.js codebases, Vercel, from 7m 25s to 1m 6s, by using our new Rust-powered compiler which scales beautifully with the number of CPU cores in build machines. Things will get even wilder once incremental caching is enabled.

2ï¸âƒ£ Partnering with the ecosystem (@rspack_dev) to make sure we speed up *everyone*, including complex webpack-centric setups & mature codebases.

Turbopack is extremely exciting, but since we started this project, we've been committed to backwards compatibility. For example, you can use 15.3 with Pages Router and styled-jsx if you'd like. In line with this commitment, we believe Rspack can help tremendously with codebases that have lots of webpack extensions that Turbopack doesn't support.

3ï¸âƒ£ Better client routing support

We've heard a lot of feedback that you want more routing flexibility client-side. Excited to give you fine-grained control for navigations. Finally an elegant way to do transition animations ğŸ«¡

and moreâ€¦ Check out the release notes:

Just chatted with a prolific @v0 creator who chats with v0 exclusively in ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡· Spanish. The quality of his results is top-notch. It seems obvious in retrospect, AI is good at natural language beyond English, but to hear it's working is a joy. 

Growing up, I first had to painstakingly learn English to become good at processing the limited information, examples, manuals, HOWTOs, community forums, IRC servers, etc, available online on the cutting-edge technical topics I was interested in.

And while obviously English is great for global reach and worth mastering, in the particular case of programming, it offered no concrete 'cognitive' benefits to me. It was just an obstacle to building and shipping. This obstacle is now being removed for billions of people.

At ~7,000 RPS, deploying several times per hour, whether youâ€™re an intern or senior member of the technical staff. 

Truly zero downtime deployments & rollbacks that propagate instantly worldwide. 

The globally atomic, skew-free nature of the system is what gives us confidence. Consider this: as a simplification, Vercelâ€™s frontend is 3 bundles: a CDN middleware function, a server rendering function, and a client side bundle. For the app to successfully load, all three not only have to be available and 200, but the versions need to be synchronized. 

Itâ€™s â€œno buenoâ€ to run middleware thatâ€™s propagating through space and time for version N of the app, then serve static assets from another version, that then invoke a route handler of another versionâ€¦ in fact, itâ€™d be catastrophic. This is what causes companies to deploy once a quarter, at midnight, or whenever their order or transaction volume is low.

text:
Iâ€™m convinced the gap in experience between a native mobile app and a mobile web app boils down primarily to user input at this point. 

The performance gap is illusory for most use-cases & devices. Safari iOS handling of how a keyboard displays, the havoc it wreaks on the page, and limited APIs to control it are a fundamental issue.

Once 120fps animations are enabled by default thatâ€™ll be the icing on the cake. But any diminishment in the ability for a human to reliably enter information into the page is a deal breaker.

@stanlyyaa @v0 Right now you can still override, so that NEXT_PUBLIC is effectively still possible. The problem is LLMs love to ship everything to the public and don't have a strong conception of the security model and how it relates to the things you're connecting to
@_yeffrey @v0 ğŸ«¡ great to hear!

Secure vibe coding

@v0 has now prevented LLMs from writing vulnerable code in 16,200+ generated applications. Concretely, it's prevented *sixteen thousand* token leaks, from AI api keys to database compromises.

How does this work?
â€¢ From a threat model perspective, v0 doesn't take LLM code for granted. We consider all code potentially incorrect or adversarial.
â€¢ Next.js makes a strong distinction between server-side tokens and client-side tokens, which are `NEXT_PUBLIC_` prefixed.
â€¢ v0 analyzes `NEXT_PUBLIC_` usage and warns the user. Because we have support for server-side code execution, the code can then be easily moved to Route Handlers / Server Actions / etc by the AI.

Further, when v0 deploys to @vercel, server-side code becomes secure Functions that run in isolated sandboxes and read encrypted environment from our built-in secure vault.

We're continuing our research and investment into guardrails so that v0 users can ship with confidence. Our goal is to make v0 generated applications more secure than human-written ones. Shoutout to @ido_pesok for laying the groundwork in this area.

One can do even better than "Loadingâ€¦" text. With Partial Prerendering, even more static data can be hoisted into the initial CDN flush. Also, it might be worth looking into skeletons vs loading text, but that's a product design observation.

In the same app they also pre-render statically as HTML. This allows them to have SPA-like dynamic behavior, combined with more traditional content pages, without having to ship 2 websites and 2 frameworks.

This is what news look like without streaming or any client `fetch`: https://t.co/f4yZGvA8n0

The initial state for the 'app' parts of the site is a Loading state, like a SPA. Unlike a SPA, but like a traditional website, in the same first load (roundtrip) we also get the data. You can see this by turning off JS which disables the <script> tags Next.js streams with: https://t.co/Mer7APrRQs

text: @nicoritschel Good call
@jessethanley @jetpackjoe_ Look at the server processing step! The vercel response is dominated by compute and large content transfer of a very large response, not a header.

Iâ€™ll give you an additional mental model for you to chew on: pull vs push. 

If a domain gets reported, you should not wait until a link gets clicked. In fact, given the risk that someone might list copy and paste the URL, you should propagate that information ahead of time.

This should work very much like suspended accounts. Every tweet and reference gets disabled recursively.

This would allow X to do whatever enforcement without nasty short urls, and itâ€™d be a more comprehensive protection for users.

Now letâ€™s assume they canâ€™t do that. The second best thing to do is to make t co fast. You can do this by making the spam and metadata database globally replicate. The time to do a check if the link is active or flagged as phishing should be less than 1ms. The round trip time from network edge to one of the 8 regions I outlined will likely be in the order of <20ms.

Thereâ€™s no universe in which my website with all its HTML and edge middleware should return 2x faster than an empty response with a Location header, from San Francisco, and it gets much worse in other parts of the world.

Hope this helps!

text:
@jessethanley @jetpackjoe_ Whatâ€™s preventing this information from being multi-region? Just like the metadata lookup of the url itself.

Notice I didnâ€™t say â€œget rid of itâ€, I said make it fast.

@jetpackjoe_ @jessethanley You can still distribute this report information globally. Thereâ€™s zero reason to slow down the internet like this. Also, Chrome handles phishing URLs as well, we donâ€™t need each social platform to MITM us
@jessethanley â€œOut of bandâ€ is the key piece. Donâ€™t block my redirect, or donâ€™t MITM

Some that come to mind:

- Infrastructure is an output, not an input. The input is developer / vibecoder intent
- Framework is the right abstraction point to capture intent & provide guardrails / defaults for optimization
- Static and dynamic are not â€œmodesâ€ of deployment. Static is best thought of as an ahead-of-time memoization / cache. Itâ€™s a â€œknown subsetâ€ of dynamic, and they can coexist in one response (PPR)
- Function is the right abstraction for interactive compute. The incoming HTTP request triggering the function invocation add vital knowledge to the scheduling / placement / load balancing systems.
- LLMs benefit greatly from well-defined abstraction boundaries that are composable and can be reasoned about locally. This is why @v0 is so good at Tailwind and React

New AI crawler in town: `DigitalOceanGenAICrawler/1.0`.

Vercel Firewall allows you to block or allow them with one click.

As an owner of a website, youâ€™ll be confronting the question of whether the crawling of your data and content for training purposes is aligned with your business interests. And by whom.

The reality of the universe is that every request and byte transferred has some computational and energetic cost, whether your vendor of choice makes that transparent to you or not. If youâ€™re running a server, the CPU cycles spent on serving an AI crawler are CPU cycles stolen from a potential legitimate visitor or customer.

Weâ€™ve collected this and other fingerprints of AI bots and added them to a template that allows you to bulk-add Firewall rules to block AI crawlers:

The DOM properties `className` and `htmlFor` were named as such to prevent conflicts with the reserved language keywords.

React decided to align itself with the DOM APIs. It could have called them `class` and safely map them to the DOM properties under the hood, especially given JSX would not have been served directly to old JS engines where the keyword could be a conflict (like IE8).

Now the shipped has sailed. Even if supported was added for `class`, the entire ecosystem has been built on top of the assumption of `className`

â€¦they start polling their servers behind the scenes. This is not 'fake time' they're adding.

This is the opportunity for a human or AI agent to start logging in to X on your behalf.

When they get to the next factor of authentication, this gate will flip from `pending` to either `2fa_sms_control` or  `2fa_app_control`.

At that point you'll go to your app and hand them the code for the account takeover to complete.

text:
Whenever Iâ€™d have a question sparked by a post on @x, I used to switch to Google.

I now ask Grok which is effortless and contextual. One tap away.

This is the â€œunbundling of Googleâ€ taking place. It used to be that Google was the â€œintelligence appâ€. Another example is IDEs and vibe-coding platforms, they retrieve docs so you donâ€™t go to big G and Stack Overflow.

Now, intelligence is being embedded directly into every single app and interface. What this means is that whoever owns high-engagement frontends is at a major advantage.

From this lens, the merger of @x and @xai is an absolute no-brainer. Engagement, high quality data, network, frontier research, all in one place. The everything AI app.

text:
HMR & AI

Over the past decade, web frameworks and bundlers have been optimizing for HMR (hot module replacement) and Fast Refresh for React. 

The main idea of HMR is that as a human developer makes changes to the source code, we want changes reflect to instantly in the web browser.

This technology is highly prolific among web developers, but less common in other ecosystems. In fact, one of my motivations for starting @nextjs as a zero-config framework was that I was absolutely over-the-moon with this capability, and while Webpack was pioneering its support, it was too tedious to configure. I wanted it batteries-included.

Over the past few years, as dependency trees have grown, icon libraries, barrel files, and npm packages proliferated, the sheer amount of frontend source code increased dramatically. So began the journey of Turbopack, which consisted in a new architecture and design, as well as rewriting the compiler to Rust, away from JavaScript-based Webpack. 

Modern compilers like Turbopack are insanely fast at HMR, and only getting faster. With its incremental design and down-to-the-metal optimization, weâ€™re giving feedback to the user in what might just be the absolute theoretical minimum of what computers are capable of. Itâ€™s not infrequent to see â€œcode to visible changeâ€ in single digit milliseconds.

While we originally conceived Turbopack for humans, I believe itâ€™s going to play a key role in the feedback loop with AI coding agents. LLMs are not full-proof at writing code. They make mistakes and need feedback, and we want to spend as little time as possible in that compiler-agent loop. They will cook, see the output or read the error, cook againâ€¦

I think more broadly this speaks to the advantage the web has in this new chapter of software development. The web is more fluid, the feedback loop faster, the deployment model ideal. AI will massively increase the number of applications written and shipped, and I believe most of them will be web based.

text:
But as a *user* I absolutely need to know if the write has been confirmed or not, which is why I like the current experience. 

This applies to so many things: e-commerce checkouts, resource deletions, sending a bank wire. Thereâ€™s definitely a place for optimistic writes, but you must carefully consider the UX implications and expectations.

@iangrayhazzard @zero__ms Optimistic mutations are also contemplated in the RSC model, but theyâ€™re opt-in, which I think is a good thing. I really like how X handles my writes in a â€œblockingâ€ way (vs optimistically adding a fake tweet to my profile) and then handles the failure case with drafts, etc

@iangrayhazzard @zero__ms Iâ€™m very open minded about it provided it delivers on the axioms I outlined: fast loads, fast navigations, no excessive initial blocking downloads.

I know that Next, RSC and e.g.: Postgres can give you this with an excellent DX (simple data queries from â€œtemplatesâ€ ala LAMP)

text:
Some people pointed out that https://t.co/Zggoe9nRo1 is very aggressive with prefetching. This is because I set it to prefetch={true} which prefetches data. Postgres is eating that up for breakfast with zero issues, but itâ€™s still opt-in. With this example I wanted to demonstrate what the ideal experience we should strive for should be.

You have another two options:
- Prefetch the loading state. This is the SPA feel. But letâ€™s not kid ourselves. People want fast content, not just fast spinners
- Not prefetch anything! This is how https://t.co/marktAlOMG works. Just block until the content is fetched on-demand.

I personally think itâ€™s awesome that developers have this kind of flexibility. I also think @nextjs could potentially do batch prefetching (I have to concede I havenâ€™t thought about this too deeply yet, no pun intended) and massively reduce the number of requests.

I believe we should as a community and industry push for the absolute fastest and most delightful experiences, not decelerate the web.

text:
One of the coolest properties of the web, that I believe we must preserve at all costs, is that each hyperlink within a system can be a portal into arbitrary amounts of complexity, *without paying that cost up front*.

If we forego this, weâ€™ll end up with Facebookâ€™s 490MB iOS[1] download, random spinners on Home Screen while apps download, and a really hard time onboarding new users.

Thereâ€™s lots of discussion on SPA vs RSC, so itâ€™s worth clarifying our vision with @nextjs.

First, instant load times are non-negotiable. Starting with when you first get linked into an app or website. Notice I donâ€™t make a distinction here: app or website. I think the web has given rise to amazing things like being linked to a GitHub PR or Vercel deploy, and getting the content you want ASAP instead of downloading a 500mb app.

But itâ€™s also absolutely paramount that *subsequent clicks or taps* are also instantaneous, which is where traditional websites fall short. Next.js accomplishes this via prefetching, otherwise we fall back into the trap of *downloading the entire codebase* for any of the possible futures the user might take.

Next.js with RSC and partial pre-rendering is the perfect platform to yield this best of both worlds situation. I think most apps will want to pre-fetch the *next screen minus the data*, and whatâ€™s cool about this is that we do it based on the viewport, and we prefetch exactly what that user will need. Including flags and experiments that the given user is enrolled in. This is, incidentally, why something like Facebook ends up getting so big. As projects grow, engineers get ambitious about experiments, features, regional capabilities, seasonal promotions, and so on. With RSC, we solve the problem that both code and data can be highly dynamic.

In short, combining really fast load times with instant page navigations, not at the expense of downloading a gigantic monolithic app ahead of time with a spinner, is how the web wins. This is why we created Next.js in the first place[2]

[2] https://t.co/KAkwL3xOZz

@consolelogwill @serafimcloud The first paragraph tries to summarize it, and Learn More should link to basically this info. But happy to iterate further if thereâ€™s anything thatâ€™s clearly better

Youâ€™re seeing this dialog because you have the option to stay on the older image optimization pricing model while you tune things.

Vercel has a new, transparent pricing image optimization pricing model that charges for the compute incurred in optimizing images as needed. Before it was per â€œsource imageâ€, now itâ€™s per transformation and cache usage. Optimizing images incurs in non-trivial amounts of computation, so it has a cost, and this better models it.

The reason we recommend optimization by default is to ensure optimal performance for users and CWV (Core Web Vitals) for your business and your SEO. As a matter of fact, this change in Next.js came from our partnership with Google Chromeâ€™s Aurora team, who noticed the vast majority of sites on the internet are shipping large images which specially hurt mobile users.

The ğŸ”‘ piece: there are plenty of options available to you, from disabling optimization, to doing it at build time, to changing the optimization provider. Sometimes itâ€™s a simple as improving the caching lifetime on the images. We wrote docs on how to manage this:

https://t.co/NlxiGg1u7X

Our goal is to always lead with transparency and options for you, and we try our best to make the web as fast a possible, by default.

@TautikA @NabhagMotivaras @vercel @Replit @Cloudflare Just sharing facts :P

You already don't need Cloudflare, which is what's probably triggering @eastdakota's anxiety and having him resort to childlike tactics and memes:

â—¾ï¸ Built-in DDoS mitigation. As I mentioned above, we actually mitigate attacks Cloudflare doesn't. We know this because some customers layer them in front of us, and we have to block Cloudflare passing on the attack.
â—¾ï¸ Firewall / WAF. You can apply custom rules based on headers, IPs. We support rate limiting and persistent actions. We have support for JA3 and JA4 TLS fingerprints, which is a mechanism to more precisely identifying potential bad actors. You can outright block, or challenge traffic to ascertain the client is a human.
â—¾ï¸ Programmable security. You can control our Firewall programmatically via REST APIs or Terraform. We also have Firewall templates for easily creating rules, like blocking AI crawlers.
â—¾ï¸ World-class, realtime observability. You can dry-run Firewall changes in log-only mode to carefully roll out changes. You can make queries over billions of datapoints in milliseconds.
â—¾ï¸ Attack Challenge Mode. If you want to have a 'break glass' "I'm under attack" measure you can click one toggle and immediately challenge traffic. 
â—¾ï¸ Secure Compute for Functions. You can run compute that's securely bound to e.g.: your AWS VPC environments. This is infinitely safer than Cloudflare's Workers approach, which has customers usually exposing their databases to the internet.

+ a long laundry list of capabilities like OIDC, RBAC, Audit Logs, â€¦

text: AI-native Google Forms that is purely conversational. You set up the form or survey by just writing down a bunch of prompts. It gives you a link you can share for people to â€œfill out the formâ€. But itâ€™s just a chat UI. Who wants to press â€œotherâ€ and fill in a little textbox when you could just answer? Just like Typeform innovated in the UI of answering, AI provides an opportunity to improve both the creation and submission experience.

AI Camera. Point your camera to something, and just like Instagram offered â€œfiltersâ€ to solve your photography skill issue, this offers a strip of little permutations of the photo. When people or AIs write code for an app, it needs to be built. Building optimizes the code and makes it a working app. The result gets deployed to a URL people can access.

Because that code can be dangerous, we need to make sure it canâ€™t hack other peopleâ€™s code and data. We achieve this by isolating it in virtual computers that need to be â€œexorcisedâ€ after. Theyâ€™re untrusted.

We now create and destroy one million of these computers a day.

Because AI is making it easier to create applications, including non-developers, we suspect this infrastructure will grow exponentially in coming years. The faster you make this build process (which Vercel is investing heavily into), the faster AI agents (which are not infallible) can learn and correct errors.

The other stuff is a bunch of technical terms of how we make these virtual machines very reliable and work as expected.

text: @rsmck @vercel This feature should always use a 'private relay' whether the user activates it or not

Vercel is now consistently handling over 1M builds a day every day.

Thatâ€™s 1M microVMs (virtual mini cloud computers) instantly booting, running user code in a secure sandbox, and being destroyed every day.

Thereâ€™s an enormous amount of complexity being handled behind the scenes by the mighty @vercel infra team so that when you click on â€œDeployâ€ in @v0, import a repo, clone a template, or run `vc` in the CLI, your application code is quickly and securely built, optimized, and deployed globally.

To meet our scale and flexibility needs, we had to build our own custom compute platform powered by Firecracker called Hive[1]. 

We orchestrate Hive clusters in multiple regions worldwide, we handle automatic failover, QoS policies across customer and plan tiers, multiple classes of hardware, pre-warming and snapshotting of containers, custom networking overlays, security patching, Dependabot thundering herdsâ€¦ We even carefully synchronize OS and Node runtime flavors with your Functions to prevent unsavory production surprises. 

I expect the vast majority of this class of compute to be orchestrated by AIs in the future. Today, when a build @v0 creates ends with a failure (like type checking errors), v0 consumes the logs output and fixes errors automatically.

The speed at which this â€œagentic loopâ€ happens is a new and very exciting optimization target for us. Stay tuned for announcements in this space.

[1] https://t.co/nptrqIHFN1

text: @pickle41968 Are you talking about the template page? Can you point out a few things I should pay attention to?
@0xRaduan @theo I like https://t.co/KJreruAVct ğŸ˜

This is a very concerning privacy gap in ï£¿ iOS devices. 

The Firewall team @vercel was debugging curious bot-like behavior emerging from an end-user IP (i.e.: a human).

The `User-Agent` header being sent by the device was very strange lookingâ€¦ Pretending to be Facebook and Twitter at once ğŸ¤¨.

Turns out that whenever you use the iOS share dialog, a request will be made *from your IP* using this User-Agent. This is quite unexpected, especially if the user is on an app designed for private communication or watching corn.

The fact that the mere act of a sharing intent has this side-effect is concerning in its own right, but it's doubly concerning that the end-user IP is leaked in the process. (If it was an absolute must to fetch metadata about the URL, a privacy-preserving proxy could be used.)

To summarize, this results in:
â—¾ï¸ A bypass of anonymization / proxying techniques that the app you're using might be implementing. It's generally "good practice" to defer to the OS sharing dialog rather than re-implementing it in every app, but the OS is throwing you under the bus.
â—¾ï¸ A mechanism for a third party / bad actor to know that a given user is making a decision to share something.
â—¾ï¸ All the consequences that come from having an end-user IP, including de-anonymization and physical location leak risks.

text: @ja3nyc @v0 Weâ€™re strongly steering v0 towards using server components and route handlers for those scenarios. We also pair with our secure @vercel vault for secret storage to prevent leaking via .env files and other common errors.

I strongly believe AIs will create *more* secure, more correct, and more performant software than humans. 

The â€œvibeâ€ in vibe coding should speak to the creative direction style, rather than the quality of the output. This is certainly our goal with @v0, prevent slop at all costs. 

Agents donâ€™t get tired, so theyâ€™ll make fewer mistakes. Itâ€™s too easy for a human today to forget to auth an endpoint. To not apply operational limits and quotas. To forget to escape and validate untrusted input. 

Interestingly enough, our CTO @cramforce recently discovered a serious vulnerability in an open source project. It involved a lack of sanitization of potentially malicious payloads in a quite subtle, unsuspecting line of code. After our responsible disclosure to their team, I found the PR that introduced their bug and ran it through a few models. Almost all frontier coding models correctly identified the high risk involved in the inlining technique used to pass data to the browser.

Itâ€™s extremely common for human programmers and human reviewers to let these issues slide. That PR was written and reviewed by experts. The same applies to every other important area of software quality. We humans might lapse, rush or simply not know enough and not ship enough tests, accessibility, caching & other performance optimizationsâ€¦ Agents wonâ€™t forget or be lazy to ship enough instrumentation and alerting so that they themselves can get paged when the site is down.

It wonâ€™t happen overnight and this future will require the coordination of both AI and traditional software engineering techniques, including frameworks, infrastructure and security-as-codeâ€¦ but it will come.

text:
We placed a bet 10 years ago that everything would be computer.

Next.js started out as a server-side rendering framework, introduced incremental page generation, and doubled down on personalizing the web. At the time, the dogma was that servers werenâ€™t needed. You were supposed to make everything static.

First we set out to prove that computers in the cloud, or servers, didnâ€™t have to be *hard* for developers. With Vercel Functions, we made scaling compute in the cloud easy, fast, and zero configuration.

Now weâ€™re proving compute can be cost-efficient, especially for AI workloads. Since launching https://t.co/Mfqozf4JBi 5 weeks ago, weâ€™ve seen 68% of our invocations seamlessly adopt our new compute paradigm of â€œserverless serversâ€. Customers are seeing up to 85% cost savings ğŸ¥¹.

Iâ€™m extremely excited about whatâ€™s coming next. Our computers, from our dev servers, to our build infrastructure, to our functions, will increasingly be in the hands of Agents, rather than humans alone. I anticipate the vast majority of @vercel deployments will soon be made by an agent of some kind, like @v0 or @windsurf_ai and @cursor_ai.

I canâ€™t wait to see the next wave of applications we *all* ship on top of these foundations.

Prediction: software development will closely resemble the evolution of self-driving cars. 

- Considered for many years intractable, now run of the mill for a large subset of rides (robotaxi), all mobility within sight.

- The key metric to watch is disengagement rate (i.e.: how frequently the human operator needs total take over coding :: driving). 

- Occasional human takeover and steering still needed (remote takeover) to get the program â€œunstuckâ€ or figure out dilemmas. 

- Success is predicated on the successful interoperability with the existing environment and tools (existing programming languages, runtimes, frameworks :: streets, signs, pedestrians), rather than resetting the landscape.

text: Example of @wolfram_alpha being chosen by the agent: "give me 50 digits of pi" https://t.co/OgamjTfD5Q https://t.co/N3OzSKkkXj

The @vercel fluid Ã— @upstash agents framework just solved one of the trickiest issues in chatbots/agents and one of my biggest pet peeves ğŸ˜†

Notice that right after submitting my message, it immediately assigns an uuid (`/wfr_KgW5xâ€¦`) to the job. At this point, my internet might flake out, I might shut my laptop lid, I might go to my phone and open the chat from thereâ€¦

What you're looking at is a resumable, durable agentic workflow that's fault tolerant on the server and on the client. On the server side, Fluid functions on @vercel will be invoked for each step, and they can fail and get retried. On the client, polling for changes ensures eventual consistency even in the presence of very long network partitions.

Shoutout to @yemreoz for collaborating with me on shipping these improvements. Check out the OSS @nextjs repo to learn these patterns and the demo at: https://t.co/ZUJCJhs1Br

ps: it's actually impressive what a wide range of questions this simple demo agent can answer by choosing between @exaailabs / @wikipedia / @wolframresearch

text: @ovidbme @codinsonn @vercel they don't support full Node and Python runtimes

We set the #0 priority for @vercel infrastructure for the year as: the fastest, most efficient, and observable build & functions compute

We shipped https://t.co/Mfqozf4JBi for speed & efficiency. Very excited about the big strides the team is making in Observability:
@jonathankennell @hyetigran FWIW most systems do a rollup / pre-aggregation before hitting the 'main chain'
@jonathankennell Correct!

@steida Yes but practically speaking people *have* written these ledgers and datastores, run them in a (semi-)decentralized fashion, have well understood correctness / durability guarantees, have support for extension via VMs / wasm smart contracts, etc. There's lots of utility there.
@sauravv_x Definitely still an opportunity

@jonathankennell The problem with the 'traditional data store' is you end up solving the same problems over and over again, introducing your own novel bugs, and ending up with fewer assurances. These systems in their 'public' variety have gone through *intense* security and correctness scrutiny.
@betimdrenica Customers want rollups of their usage data over their entire account's lifetime

All the problems that infra and AI companies face with consumption billing (high-throughput usage data logs, credits/precommits, o11y, open APIs, budgets, wallets) should have been solved by some kind of enterprise / hybrid blockchain solution. Crypto fell asleep at the wheel.

Huge milestone on @nextjs Turbopack production builds achieved internally.

Vercel has one of the largest Next.js monorepos in the world. It's 8+ years old, has 65,000 modules, 7,800 dependencies, 70 active committers in Feb.

The unlock: build speed scales with number of cores. We're building a gigantic app, cold, in ~1 minute. The bet on ğŸ¦€ @rustlang's support for shared-memory parallelism (an Achilles heel of JS-based tooling) is paying off wonderfully.

Where do we go from here? 
â€¢ Keep an eye on areweturboyetâ .com for progress
â€¢ Incremental builds will be another dramatic speedup â€“ the other reason we bet on a new compiler architecture
â€¢ More memory and cold perf optimizations

text: @GroqInc Congrats! Excited for whatâ€™s to come

@realshcallaway I would argue local-first is a very aggressive form of prefetching (which is why these apps usually have a very large cold-start penalty). The rule above stays: you have to have a backend fast and scalable enough to seed the data quickly and to propagate the deltas.

Best @v0 3d challenge entry yet 
https://t.co/KSJiwo4i9t

Itâ€™s impossible to create a fast frontend without a fast backend.

Some notable exceptions that help accelerate a frontend *in spite* of a slow or resource constrained backend:

â€¢ ISR. The simplest explanation of ISR is that itâ€™s a view materialization in db lingo. The inputs to that view can be slow or even partially unavailable. But once the materialization is done by the Vercel infra, it becomes *our* problem not yours. We can globally persist it, synchronize it and virtually deliver it at the speed of light

â€¢ Partial Pre-rendering. Related to ISR, but even for a highly dynamic view, we can extract the static or semi-static (think: CMS content) parts of the page and ensure their globally availability. Even if the dynamic holes of the page are slow, we flush instantly from the CDN edge, and concurrently begin to initialize dynamic resources. While the client starts to load the static <head> including critical CSS, weâ€™re parallelizing the dynamic timeline. Game changing 

â€¢ Pre-fetching. Iâ€™ve called this â€œnegative latencyâ€ in the past. PPR and static ISR pages can be automatically prefetched based on viewport and intent signals. Next.js also lets you easily prefetch dynamic content. These techniques give highly complex pages with lots of dynamic data the feeling of an app thatâ€™s downloaded all its data locally ahead of time. It also solves for the false dichotomy of SPA vs SSR. Transitions and clicks feel instant, but you now have the ability to avoid waterfalls and get the dynamic data faster.

Overall, youâ€™ll always have to worry about your data backends being fast. Next.js has been investing heavily in observability out of the box to this end (OpenTelemetry). Iâ€™m also a huge fan of the @vercel Observability feature that automatically captures metrics for outgoing HTTP destinations (as an aside, a phenomenal side effect of the ecosystem standardizing on `fetch`). Vendors like headless CMS, BaaS and e-commerce providers need to be held accountable to their APIs p99s and error rates, Vercelâ€™s shields and caches non-withstanding ğŸ˜Š

@xyz3va Great find and appreciate the responsible disclosure

Fundamentally, Next.js has always been an API framework. 

A core design tenet is that once an app is first loaded, subsequent navigations should be â€œsoftâ€ and snappy, to avoid restarting everything.

When `getServerSideProps` and `getStaticProps` were introduced, we ensured a special â€œAPI endpointâ€ was produced behind the scenes to serve a .json representation of the page. Thatâ€™s whatâ€™s fetched when you use <Link> and that makes Next pages fast.

[As interesting trivia, the process of extracting the code to produce that server function was super non-trivial (i.e.: â€œdead code eliminationâ€). We produced a not super well-known tool at the time so you could visualize this (https://t.co/8T9e6WBUHq), but in the end it was altogether quite hacky and you can get an idea of why â€œuse serverâ€ and â€œuse clientâ€ are such a great evolution.]

gSSP was in many ways poor manâ€™s React Server Components, but the fate was sealed that @nextjs would be a full stack framework. With RSC DX and caching improvements well underway, we can start to turn our attention to other core pieces of the backend side of Next. 

Weâ€™re shipping improvements to Middleware (with @nodejs being supported experimentally in 15.2), and weâ€™ll be investing in even better support for defining APIs via Route Handlers, starting with better documentation and a way to start an API-only project:

$ npx create-next-app@latest --api

text: âœ¨ enhance

Part of the success of AI for code generation is explained by the fact that LLMs are indisputably great at it.

But it's also that the best way to build great products is to be your own customer. We're still in the early innings of the intelligence age, and the few people who understand AI deeply are engineers, who are highly motivated to scratch their own itches, and get their friends onboard.

If anything, this makes me even more bullish about what AI will do to other fields of human endeavor.

text: @NicolasBuilds @v0 @vercel We have a culture of DM-minimization
@LifeOfPhat @v0 @vercel @meetgranola Just my experience
@sauravv_x @v0 @vercel I meet with people casually and spontaneously all the time vs creating a packed calendar

On meetings & productivity:
â€¢ You likely don't need that meeting
â€¢ APIs and docs > bizdev / partnership meetings
â€¢ That meeting could have been a @v0 / @vercel deploy
â€¢ Work doesn't need to wait until the meeting, start now
â€¢ Meetings pile up, need recurring garbage collection
â€¢ Useful and necessary meetings exist
â€¢ Meetings are essential to know & understand people
â€¢ In-person spontaneity is better than a packed agenda
â€¢ Information wants to be free. If in doubt: work in public
â€¢ @meetgranola solves memory & dissemination
â€¢ Don't mistake having meetings with accomplishment

A neat thing about @nextjs is that you can totally use it in its simplest mode, a static page or SPA.

But itâ€™s likely youâ€™ll eventually need more, which is what many, the @reactjs team at @meta specially, figured out over time.

And if/when you need that extra power, the tools are there, waiting for you. No need to rewrite or start your project over. Whether itâ€™s a Route Handler (API endpoint), streaming data from the server to client (`use`), or full on server side rendering and streaming. Or a combination of these things.

Our recent improvements to defaults and how caching works (â€œuse cacheâ€) are in the service of the â€˜progressive disclosureâ€™ of this sophistication. Not every project will grow to that level of complexity, and thatâ€™s fine, because the platform scales with you.

Anecdotally, what Iâ€™ve found so far is that most Next.js projects end up in a hybrid state. https://t.co/CzVegAMfnq, https://t.co/y2vORgcqrX and https://t.co/4h5BByoYoH mostly present as a SPA. But: v0 Community is like an e-commerce website and we heavily optimize for SEO, while the chat and preview are like a native app.

Even in the realm of e-commerce, like https://t.co/C2q4ESzL6K where we make heavy use of on-demand ISR, some pages are fully personalized and never cached, like your orders page. And every single page has a dynamically streamed â€œholeâ€ for the cart state and user auth.

tl;DR: donâ€™t feel pressured to use every feature. Next mirrors React insofar it can start simple and grow into powering very ambitious things. The focus over recent releases has been to focus on simplicity and stability to match that progression.

@vercel_changes Good default
@zaiste @yournextstore @vercel Nice

Took a peek at how @grok DeepSearch is implemented, it's very neat.

One thing that stood out to me is that it's resilient to aborting the stream half-way and refreshing the page. Most chatbots struggle with this.

When they initially render the conversation, it detects whether the response is in-flight. If it's in-flight, there's a dedicated endpoint (`/rest/app-chat/conversations/reconnect-response/`) that can handle the resumption of streaming updates.

They use NDJSON (newline delimited JSON) and a simple streaming parser with async generators. Frequent updates are batched together for perf reasons.

Overall this is one of my favorite @nextjs App Router implementations to date and it raises the bar in terms of performance, reliability and design. Helping other people solve this 'resumption' problem has been high on my list (as far back as when I designed https://t.co/v6M4VQNaw0), and I'm impressed @xai shipped a solution this early on.

(Note: this is all from a quick cursory read of the client JS bundles and network activity)

text: @oricie @v0 I think the team has been improving this area a lot recently â€” worth trying again and if not lmk
@oricie @v0 I pasted the flight api url and told it to use it. It walked me through adding the env variable

While flying I like to track my flight, but it was slow & ugly so I started building @v0â ing my own. Some insights:

â€¢ I started out with test data, but adding an API key & server endpoint to get actual flights was a breeze
â€¢ I got back 20,000 flights which murdered DOM performance. v0 suggested implementing it as a <canvas>. With some @grok research help, it shockingly nailed it.

Notably, it used an OffscreenCanvas to render the airplane SVG to and subsequently `drawImage` it. It got approximately 100x faster and smoother.

Everything at @vercel is built using feature flags, including dogfooding @nextjs ones. This approach boosts quality, confidence, and it solves the hardest problem in computer science: marketing.

Fluid compute went through *extensive* internal use before GA: billions of invocations across dozens of projects. We're now doing that for Next.js with "use cache", PPR, Turbopack for prodâ€¦

Once the tech works, the marketing story is straightforward and honest: "we / early adopters used this tech to build these products we're proud of, developers and end-users are happier, and business metrics improved. Here's how you can do it too."

Indeed. Proxies are undesirable because they add latency, lessen availability and security. They made sense when the thing they proxied to was not a global network itself, but an on-premises server in a rack.

There's an interesting metaphor between the personal computing era and the personal software era.

Personal computing was about decentralizing the power to use software. Thanks to AI, personal software is about the decentralization of its creation and distribution.

In the case of PCs, I'd argue that the "home computer" aspect of "personal" was significant, but lesser than the impact to businesses and enterprises. After all, the true personal computer ended up being the mobile phone.

Prior to PCs, business users were massively bottlenecked in accessing software and information. The computing scarcity was such that "timesharing" was invented so that multiple users could use the same costly mainframe machine.

If you look at software development at companies, you see the same bottleneck. Instead of "timesharing" a computer, you're time-sharing the limited and overwhelmed software development teams. Developer time is precious. It's hard to recruit, hire, onboard, and train, but crucially, it's hard to get them to *understand the business*.

Piles and piles of software have been invented to 'sort out' that bottleneck, with TODO lists and Kanban boards, and cults like agile and scrum or whatever. A lot of jobs have even been invented to act as a "translation layer" between the technical mind and the business mind.

Personal software will forever break this dichotomy. With tools like @v0, any person in the org chart can start building. They will build with the same infrastructure and components as the Real Engineersâ„¢. They will deploy to the same robust and scalable cloud infrastructure.

History rhymes but seldom repeats exactly. The PC revolution had Moore's law tailwinds that led to faster computation, but the personal software era has AI scaling law tailwinds that lead to superintelligence. Eventually software will be self-writing, self-improving, and not just personal but personalized to us. As the paradigm shifts, we'll have to optimize for truth-seeking, open, and freedom-optimizing AI that's best aligned with our personal goals and interests.

text:
@che_sampat @steren @vercel Unacceptable cold start times (at the time, haven't looked in a while!). Vercel is massively-multi-tenant and we wanted to blur the lines of static and dynamic.

Kudos to both Google & AWS though in the respective dimensions. Fluid brings both sides of the innovation to market.
@elie2222 @NeeravPVyas @vercel Investigating, canâ€™t repro so far. It should launch a modal. Have you not seen this?
@tomlienard @vercel Great explanation. It's almost as if you had your hands all over this product ğŸ˜

This brings the edge worker / runtime chapter for Vercel to a close.

The lessons:
â—† Developers want full, open runtimes. A cloud runtime that promises efficiencies and has DX and ecosystems tradeoffs ain't it. We brought the compute efficiencies and cold start improvements to the existing ecosystem instead, and that's Fluid.

â—† "Edge" is for routing, static assets, and prerendersâ€¦ not for apps, APIs & databases. Fluid is multi-region, optimizing for running your app next to your Postgres, as God through the laws of physics intended. But multi-region is not dozens or hundreds of CDN edges. Google Spanner, Turso, and Amazon DSQL are leading the charge here in helping you go global in an economical and actually performant way.

â—† It's over for v8 Isolates as a cloud primitive. If we can bring I/O efficiency to microVMs with broad runtime support, the huge security tradeoff in using *the JS engine* as your virtualization layer becomesâ€¦ a strange value proposition to say the least ğŸ˜µâ€ğŸ’«

In fact, as of last week, all Edge Middleware runs on Fluid in the Vercel cloud. As I've shared[1], it's actually even faster and more efficient than before (and runtime agnostic, with @nodejs coming soon to @nextjs), while also being more secure.

[1]
https://t.co/jzxJOsFT70

We're evaluating a change to Real Experience Score that'll raise the performance bar for the web. We'll make FCP, LCP, TTFB more demanding for ğŸŸ¢ on Desktop.

FCP: good <= 900ms (was 1.8s)
LCP: good <= 1.2s (was 2.5s)

Motivation: the alignment today was driven by parity with Core Web Vitals, which have the same Good thresholds for Mobile and Desktop. 

In practice, we see that Mobile is far more challenging due to power- and networking-constrained devices. Desktop should be able to realize much faster speeds in practice, and the proposed scoring reflects that.

Think of this as going to the gym but for the web ğŸ˜

text:
@biiishal Don't want to pick on vendors, it's more so the architecture  that's broken. 

Modern hyperscalers like AWS (in tandem with Vercel) already have a massive network infrastructure footprint, so it makes putting something in front 100% redundant. Slower, less available, less secure.

This week, a large multinational retail customer of Vercel got rid of the redundant CDN vendor in front of us.

The result: major cost savings *and* performance improvements. ~150ms TTFB reductions as measured by field data, which is what their customers experience and what Google ranks them on.

These vendors tend to boast their number of PoPs (points of presence), increased performance, and DDoS mitigation capabilities. In practice, we've found that their marketing does not match reality whatsoever.

Excited to power a more secure, dynamic and generative web for everyone, by default. I look forward to sharing more stories and data from the field over coming weeks and months!

The three chapters of the web
1ï¸âƒ£ Static
2ï¸âƒ£ Dynamic 
3ï¸âƒ£ Generative     â†’ you are here

The past 10 years were about upgrading the web from static documents and CDN cached content, to a dynamic medium

In that context Next.js flourished, static frameworks fell out of style, and React came a server-driven UI framework.

The future is generative. Less and less we will depend on Software 1.0 rendering instructions. UI will flow as a function of context and prompts and according to the user needs.

Only a handful of companies have been able to historically leverage the web medium like this, most notably Google. Now everybody can cook.

text:
Misconception: SEO doesn't matter anymore, we're all going to answer engines like @perplexity_ai.

Reality: answer engines and agents search the web to be up to date, and the motivation to rank high in *those* search results is still there.

BUT things are changing as Google continues to get "unbundled":
â—¾ï¸ Answer engines are not going to (exclusively) use Google Search. @grok notably [pictured below] merges in a first-party feed of @x posts.
â—¾ï¸ Large clusters of queries are going to expert, in-situ AI products like @v0 and @cursor_ai. The search is not being made, because v0 can go straight to the sources that it's highly optimized for (and cutting out SEO spam like w3schools!)
â—¾ï¸ The crawling, indexing, and source curation infrastructure is rapidly decentralizing. @exaailabs produces curated "websets" for expert AI systems to consume. It's very likely agents will prefer to query these than performing 'generic' web searches.
â—¾ï¸ As a website or product owner, while you previously mostly had to use one thing to understand your SEO health (Google Search Console / Webmaster Tools), now you have to worry about what the large AI chatbots say about you and your brand. This is not limited to search results, but also what the LLM overall "thinks" about you. Products like @tryprofound are looking to help you scale this monitoring.

text: There's definitely a fit, but I suspect the motivation hasn't been there because it's a good "compile-time API" rather than a runtime one (and IMO this is true for modules as well)

@iamsahaj_xyz Per the metaphor, if your friend is asking to get started with Linux, odds are 99% they actually want GNU/Linux and a distribution. It's a tricky balance to find: some people go to `https://t.co/bNTCaFGztb` looking to "compile the kernel", but most people just want an OS
@ddaalee i hope not ğŸ¤£

React has become the 'linux kernel' of modern software development. The industry has broadly standardized around its 'syscall interface', from vendors shipping hooks or components as their SDKs, to LLMs being trained to generate it.

The metaphor holds further. Today, Linux is mostly used in the form of distributions that bundle it. Most users are oblivious to what kernel version they're even running, because they're interested in a working operating system with all the necessary tools to be productive, as well as an app ecosystem, support, and security patches.

A lot of people start using React by (sometimes unknowingly) assembling their own 'distributions' aka frameworks. This is akin to checking out the Linux source, running `make vmlinux`, then re-assembling the operating system by hand. I think this is a very cool thing to learn and do, and early in my career I'm very thankful I bootstrapped my own Linux systems with projects like LFS and Gentoo. It built character ğŸ˜† and foundational knowledge.

If you're building a product or a company, I strongly recommend you pick a distribution, not assemble one. Next.js is the most popular, but naturally many others have emerged: TanStack, Remix, Astro, Waku to name a few great ones, built by passionate, expert "kernel" engineers.

The most important metric is not the p99 latency of your backend api, itâ€™s for how long the customerâ€™s eyes stared at a loading animation / skeleton / blank page / progress bar.

Thanks to React, we have a reification of the loading state which we can measure: the `fallback` of a <Suspense> boundary (as an aside, an advantage of RSC over hooks-based data fetching).

This is why frontend-native, e2e observability is king. Start with the customer experience and work backwards to backend and infrastructure.

A huge % of the feedback I find myself giving to early stage founders boils down to: remove the friction between the user and the creation of the core "entity" or "resource" your company is facilitating (be it a 'search query', 'image generation', 'document', 'deployment'â€¦)

I just saw an incredible demo from a founder that casually brushed off the fact that before creating the "thing" in their product, you first had to create a "folder" to hold the "thing" (the folder being completely inconsequential).

Founders live so deep into their product they frequently forget they accidentally set up 10 layers of indirection and non-obvious obstacles before that 'aha' moment.

We've begun moving large parts of the @vercel core backend API toÂ¹ be self-hosted on @vercel, barring circular dependenciesÂ² for bootstrapping

To give you context, the scope is:
âºï¸ 2.5B weekly API requests
âºï¸ Daytime peaks ~7,000 RPS
âºï¸ Idle hours ~2,000 RPS
âºï¸ p50 response time 65ms

Why is this exciting for everyone?
âºï¸ Battle-tests our runtime support for backends
âºï¸ Better documents the K8S â†’ Vercel migration story
âºï¸ Thanks to our new sÌ¶eÌ¶rÌ¶vÌ¶eÌ¶rÌ¶lÌ¶eÌ¶sÌ¶sÌ¶ Ì¶sÌ¶eÌ¶rÌ¶vÌ¶eÌ¶rÌ¶sÌ¶, err, in-function concurrency, we're confident about its cost-efficiency
âºï¸ Will increase our iteration velocity 

Given how hard it is to scale and roll back APIs when you're not using serverless systems (in the realm of 1000s of K8s pods), I also anticipate this will make our APIs faster, more reliable, and easy to upgrade. Will keep you posted on latency improvements.

Â¹ lots of non-core APIs are already self-hosted on @vercel and @v0 is fully self-hosted

Itâ€™s so paradoxical and hard to build an intuition for that youâ€™re just better off building software ğŸ˜

@mignano @pontusab @middayai @languine_ai @nextjs and better tbh. He shared he's had perfect uptime, no anomalies, no complaints. I pressedâ€¦ I wanted something juicy for the infra team ğŸ˜

Just had an incredibly illuminating conversation with @pontusab about how he's building @middayai and @languine_ai on Vercel.

Example: Midday has 150+ @nextjs Server Actions already. In his previous life, this would have been a soul-wrenching microservice fleet ğŸ¥´. Even a separate REST API would massively degrade his iteration velocity.

It takes a village: lots of products are making this single-engineer feat of supporting the backend of 10,000+ businesses possible: @supabase, @triggerdotdev, @tursodatabase, @aisdk. 

He also gets frequent attacks, and our built-in security features and support for rate-limiting has saved the day on more than one occasion. Another tidbit is that using Turbopack for Languine has been night-and-day for DX.

I hope his journey inspires others. Go check out his products & open source contributions!
